When Shiva is described as Mahadeva or the Deva of all Devas, you should understand that there is a hierarchy among Devas. Among all the Devas, four personalities have that special position. First one is Brahma. Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva are called Chiraloka Pala. They are the permanent governors of this universe. That means their position does not change throughout the duration of the whole universe. All other personalities who are holding positions of power, all other Devatas, their duration is of a limited time. Maximum is one Manvantara, 71 Mahayugas, that's it. After that they have to quit their position. Whereas Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva, throughout the duration of the whole universe, they don't change their position. Among the three, Brahma is actually a Jeeva, a living entity. But Brahma is immune to all the changes that take place in the universe during the life span of Brahma himself. So he is unaffected by anything that happens. But greater than Brahma is Shiva because Shiva is not a Jeeva. Shiva is not a living entity. Brahma has to die. Shiva has no death. Shiva doesn't have a material body. That's why he doesn't have to die. Death means what? Quitting the material body is called death. Soul has no death. None of us have death. So even Brahma doesn't have death as soul. But when you say Brahma also has to die means he has to leave his body as Brahma. That Brahma's body. He has to leave that. He has to quit that. But Shiva, he doesn't have a material body. He never accepts a material body.

### Lord Jagannath, Indra Dhyumna, Neelamadhava, Darubrahman
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/dOA9Bi8lmlo?t=51

**Summary:** The story begins with King Indra Dhyumna's desire to see Lord Vishnu, the discovery of Neelamadhava, and the eventual instruction to build a temple where the Lord would manifest as Darubrahman.

Today is the day of the Rathayatra of Lord Jagannath, Baldev, and Subhadra. The story of Lord Jagannath is given in the Skanda Purana. I will try to narrate that story very briefly. There was a king by the name Indra Dhyumna, who was a great devotee of Vishnu. Indra Dhyumna became very eager to meet Lord Vishnu face to face. Once a Brahmana came to the palace of King Indra Dhyumna and told him about an incarnation of Lord Vishnu named Neelamadhava. The king then sent different brahmanas out to search for the deity of Lord Neelamadhava. They all returned unsuccessful except for one priest by name Vidyapati. Vidyapati travelled for a long time, after which he came to an area inhabited by non-Aryans called Shabaras. He stayed at the house of a local chief whose name was Vishwavasu. When he arrived, Vishwavasu was not there, but Vishwavasu's daughter Lalitha was at home. Vidyapati stayed there for some time, and eventually married Lalitha, the daughter of the Shabara chief, Vishwavasu. Vidyapati noticed some peculiar behavior of his host. Vishwavasu would go out every day around noon and would return to the house scented with fragrance of sandalwood, camphor, and musk. Vidyapati asked his wife about this and she informed him that her father went to worship him. Lalitha had been told by her father not to tell anyone about Neelamadhava, but that was in advance of her order. She was to be told by her father. Lalitha else had to announced any decision. By this, Linda had been pinched from mud Meela made clear her duty to his husband. विद्यापती रिपीटेडली रिक्वेस्टेड तो सी नीलमाधवा। फाइनली विश्वावसु ललितास फादर बाउन्ड विद्यापतीस आईस आन्ड टुक हिम तो सी नीलमाधवा। विद्यापती सीक्रत्ली कैरिट सम्मस्टर्ड सीट्स इन इस क्लॉथ आणि ड्रॉप्ट देम अन्द पाथ आज ही वस वाकिंग। वाल ही रीच्ट नीलमाधवा द ब्लाइंटफोल्ड वस रिमोव्ड आणि विद्यापती सो नीलमाधवा। Vishwavasu went out to collect some forest flowers to worship Neelamadhava, and Vidyapati stayed near the Deity. During this time, a crow fell off the branch of a tree into a nearby lake and drowned. It immediately took a four-armed Vaikuntha form and started back to the spiritual world. Vidyapati then climbed up onto the tree and was about to jump into the lake. A voice from the sky said, "Since you have seen Neelamadhava, you should inform King Indra." Vishwavasu returned and started his daily worship of Neelamadhava. Suddenly the Lord spoke to him and said, "I have accepted many days the simple forest flowers and roots offered to me by you. Now I desire the royal worship offered to me in devotion by King Indra Dhyumna." Vishwavasu felt cheated by his son-in-law. Therefore, he bound him up and kept him in his house. After repeatedly being requested by his daughter, he let him go. The Brahmana, with these words, said, "The Brahmana, Vidyapati, then went to King Indra Dhyumna and told him about his discovery. By following the mustard seeds which had grown into small plants, they were able to follow the path to Neelamadhava. When they reached the spot, they could not find him. King Indra Dhyumna had the village besieged and arrested Vishwavasu. Suddenly a voice from the sky told, "Release the Shabara. On top of Neela hill, you should construct a temple. There I will manifest as Darubrahman, the absolute truth manifested in a wooden form."

You will not see me as Neelamadhava. King Indra Dhyumna constructed a temple. He wanted Lord Brahma to consecrate the temple, so he travelled to Brahmaloka and waited there for him. During this time, the temple became covered by sand. While Indra Dhyumna was gone, first Suradeva and then Galamadhava became king of the area. King Galamadhava uncovered the temple from the sand. Shortly afterwards, King Indra Dhyumna returned from Brahma's abode. Indra Dhyumna claimed that he had built the temple, and Galamadhava also claimed the same thing. There was an old crow in the nearby banyan tree who was constantly singing the glories of Lord Rama. The crow had seen the construction of the temple and said that Indra Dhyumna had built the temple and that Gala Madhava had just uncovered it. Because he had not told the truth, Gala Madhava was ordered by Brahma to live outside the temple compound on the western side of Indra Dhyumna Sarovara lake. Indra Dhyumna then asked Lord Brahma to consecrate the temple and the surrounding area which was called Sri Kshetra. He gave the highest type of liberation. Lord Brahma told him that Sri Kshetra is manifested by the Supreme Lord's internal potency and that the Supreme Lord manifests Himself. Therefore, he could not install the Lord here. Lord Jagannath and his abode are eternally situated in the material world. He said he would install the flag on the temple that anyone who sees this flag and offers prostrated obeisances would easily be liberated.

As is evident from this record in the Srimad Bhagavatam and the Mahabharata, it is very clear that even in the days 5000 years back, there was this separation of the men and women. There was no free mixing. And it is a very important point to be noted. So, Srila Prabhupada says, "This incident from the Mahabharata period proves definitely that the ladies of the palace observed strict parda, restricted association with men. And instead of coming down in the open air where Lord Krishna and others were assembled, the ladies of the palace went up on top of the palace and from there paid their respects to Lord Krishna by showers of flowers." So, they showed their respect. They maintained the distance. At the same time, the respect that was being given was very evident by their action, showering flowers upon the Lord. It is definitely stated here in this verse that the ladies were smiling there on the top of the palace, checked by shyness. Both are mentioned. Prema vrida smitekshanaha. Now, prema is out of affection and love. Vrida is glancing with shyness. So, Prabhupada particularly comments about this shyness, that this shyness is a gift of nature to the fair sex, and it enhances their beauty and prestige, even if they are of a less important family, or even if they are less attractive. It's a very important point. Women generally are more attractive than men, but in case, in some instances, women are not so attractive, but still shyness enhances their beauty, and even their prestige. So, this, Srila Prabhupada explains further, "We have practical experience of this fact." And what is that experience that Prabhupada is narrating here? "A sweeper woman commanded the respect of many respectable gentlemen simply by manifesting a lady's shyness." Prabhupada is talking of his times, say about 80 years back. The sweeper woman, who is not very, not a high class lady, but still, because of her shyness, she was commanding the respect of even big gentlemen in the society. On the other hand, Prabhupada comments, "Half naked ladies in the street do not command any respect, but a shy sweeper's wife commands respect from all." So, shyness is such an important quality for a woman.

### illusion, material vs. spiritual beauty, detachment, Vedic wisdom
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/GHxEhqfE3jU?t=593
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The real beauty is within and the real beauty belongs to the soul, not to the body."
**Summary:** The speaker explains that material beauty is an illusion, as the body is made of temporary elements, and that true beauty lies within the spirit soul, urging listeners to not be attracted by false, external beauty.

And it is very, very important. Human civilization as conceived of by the sages of India is to help one free himself from the clutches of illusion. Everyone here in this material world, men, women of whichever class, whichever standard, are all in the clutches of maya, illusion, as conditioned souls. But, the sages are instructing us to lead a particular lifestyle to become free from these clutches of the illusory energy. The material beauty of a woman is an illusion because actually the body is made of earth, water, fire, air, etc. But because there is association of the living spark with matter, this material body appears to be beautiful. Kindly note this carefully, that a woman appears attractive only because the material body is actually in contact with the living spark, the life due to the spirit soul within the body. And Prabhupada gives an example to illustrate this. No one is attracted by an earthen doll even if it is the most perfectly prepared doll to attract the attention of others. You have seen mannequins in stores which sell, let's say, some garments. They dress up a doll of a woman very nicely. Now, everyone knows this doll is actually lifeless and nobody is attracted to such a doll. So, therefore, the dead body has no beauty because no one will accept the dead body of a so-called beautiful woman. Therefore, the conclusion is that the spirit spark is beautiful and because of the soul's beauty, one is attracted by the beauty of the outward body. So, the real beauty is within and the real beauty belongs to the soul, not to the body. Therefore, the lesson to be learnt is the Vedic wisdom forbids us to be attracted by false beauty. Don't be attracted by material beauty. Don't be attracted by external beauty.

The real beauty is within. But because we are now in the darkness of ignorance, the Vedic civilization allows very restricted mixing of men and women. So, the sages of the Vedic civilization, they say that the woman is considered to be like fire and the man is considered to be butter. Butter must melt in the association of fire. Therefore, they may be brought together only when it is necessary. Men and women are brought together only when absolutely essential. And shyness is a check to the unrestricted mixing. The real beauty is inside, within, of the spirit, not of the body. So, don't be attracted by bodily beauty. And we all know this bodily beauty is highly flickering. It is very, very short-lived. Vedascha sarvair ahameva vedyo. By all the Vedas am I to be known. Krishna says this in the Bhagavad Gita. And Srila Prabhupada says further, factually the glories of the Lord are depicted in such literature as the Vedas, Ramayana and Mahabharata. This is also mentioned in the scriptures: Vede Ramayane chaiva purane bharate tatha. Aadavantecha madhyecha hari sarvatra giyate. The meaning of this verse is, in the Vedic literature, including the Ramayana, Puranas and Mahabharata, from the very beginning, Aadav, to the end, Antecha, as well as within the middle, Madhyecha, only Hari, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, is explained, is glorified. And in the Bhagavatam, they are specifically mentioned in respect to the Supreme Lord. Bhagavata is Krishna Katha. It is exclusive glorification of Krishna from the beginning till the end, throughout the Bhagavatam.

Prabhupada says, the Vedic hymns in the Upanishads are sometimes indirectly directed to the Supreme Lord. The Upanishads are actually the philosophical portions of the Vedas which describe the Absolute Truth. And the Absolute Truth is described both impersonal and personal. So the impersonal descriptions are very prominent in the Upanishads portions of the Vedas. Whereas, the personal aspect of the Absolute Truth, that is the Personality of Godhead, Krishna, Rama, Narsimha, Varaha, all the incarnations are more nicely described in detail in the Puranas, Itihasas, like Ramayana, entirely about Lord Rama. Mahabharata, about Krishna and many other incarnations. Bhagavatam, fully about Krishna and his incarnations. So the Puranas are describing the personal feature of the Absolute Truth. Therefore, the discussions or the descriptions in the Puranas, Itihasas, about the personal feature of the Lord are more attractive and pleasing to hear than the descriptions in the Upanishads. Therefore, it is said the ladies' talks were more attractive than the Vedic hymns.

So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, as mentioned above, the cosmic creation is the property of the Supreme Lord. This world, we think it belongs to us, but actually it belongs to Krishna. This is the basic philosophy of the Isha Upanishad. The first to punish it among all the punishments, Isha Upanishad, there it is explained, every one of us is a part of the Supreme Lord, and we are all part of the Supreme Lord. Everything is the property of the Supreme being: Isha vasya idam sarvam yatkincha jagattyam jagat. So therefore, no one should encroach upon the property of the Supreme Lord: tena tyaktena bunjitha maa grudakasya svidhanam. One should accept only what is kindly awarded by him. Therefore, the earth or any other planet or universe is the absolute property of the Supreme Lord Krishna. The living beings are certainly his parts and parcels or sons, and thus every one of them has a right to live at the mercy of the Lord to execute his prescribed work. It belongs to Krishna does not mean we are not entitled to any portion of any resource in this world. It doesn't mean that. We have an entitlement as his son, as his child, as his amsha, but we have a right to only a tiny portion which is our actual requirement for executing the prescribed duties.

No one therefore can encroach upon the right of another individual man or animal without being so sanctioned by the Lord. The Lord's sanction is required if we have to encroach upon others. We cannot encroach, and if we do so unlawfully, we are punishable by the laws of Krishna, called the laws of material nature, the laws of God. The king or the administrator is a representative of the Lord to look after the management of the Lord's will. The sun arises from the eastern horizon, but that does not mean that the eastern horizon is the parent of the sun. Is it that the sun is being generated out of the eastern horizon? No. The sun exists. Even before it appears on the eastern horizon, the sun is existing. In its position, relative to our vision, the sun becomes visible in the eastern horizon at a certain time. And about 12 hours later, the sun sets on the western horizon. The sun is existent in every part of the solar system. But he becomes visible at a scheduled time. And so also becomes invisible at another scheduled time. Sunrise, sunset. Becomes visible at sunrise. And the sun becomes invisible at sunset. So this is a very good example to help us understand. Similarly, the Lord appears in this universe like the sun and again leaves our sight at another time. He exists at all times at every place. Krishna is present everywhere. And always He is present. But by His causeless mercy, when He appears before us, we take it for granted that He has taken His birth. janma karma chame divyam. That's what is being described here. Now, Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport: Religious rites prescribed in the scriptures are meant to purify the mundane qualities of the conditioned souls. Mundane qualities means material qualities. And these material qualities are to be purified. Because we are spirit soul, we are spiritual by nature, we have spiritual qualities which are covered by material body, by material mind, covered with material qualities. So the religious rituals described in the scriptures are meant to purify the mundane qualities of the conditioned souls by these material qualities. And what will happen if we get purified? We are gradually promoted to the stage of rendering transcendental service to the Supreme Lord Krishna. So this purification is necessary for elevating us gradually to the stage of being able to serve Krishna, to be able to recognize and render devotional service to Krishna. So devotional service is not an ordinary activity, and not everybody can take to devotional service simply by desiring or deciding to do so. No. There is a lot of difference between bhakti and karma. Bhakti is completely spiritual. Karma is material. Karma may be performed by any human being, but bhakti is only for those who are purified by the right process described in the scriptures, the religious rituals for purification. And only then one can actually begin devotional service to Krishna.

There was only one king, there was one flag, there was one religion until the time of Maharaj Pariksit at least, as we have information from the records, historical records in the Puranas and the Tehasas. Maharaj Yudhishtira's younger brothers were acting as his ministers and commanders of state, and there was full cooperation between the perfectly religious brothers of the king. There was full cooperation, so there was no fight for supremacy because primarily they are devotees. They accept Krishna as the supreme lord, supreme controller, and if Yudhishtira is sitting on the throne, he is sitting as the representative of Krishna. He is ruling exactly according to the directions given in the shastras by Krishna himself, and therefore there is no question of any one person enjoying. As was mentioned in the first verse, Yudhishtira Maharaj could not have enjoyed freely with unrestricted consciousness, "Oh, this kingdom I have won, now I can enjoy all the power and the wealth and the resources, natural resources." No, that was not his mood. That is never the mood of a devotee. That is never the mood of a religious or righteous person. One should accept only what is necessary for his own subsistence, understanding that everything belongs to Krishna. So nobody can claim proprietorship over what is actually rightfully belonging to the supreme personality of Godhead, who is referred to as Isavasya in the Isha Upanishad, the first of the Upanishads. That Upanishad explains everything belongs to God, everything belongs to Krishna. So Yudhishtira Maharaj never thought, "Oh, this whole kingdom is mine, I can enjoy." No, everything belongs to Krishna. As a representative of Krishna, I should rule according to the codes of direction given in Dharmashastras by Krishna.

### Etiquette, Humility of Krishna, Krishna's Pastimes, Devotion, Personal vs. Impersonal aspect of God
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/XWi-tEQus3A?t=58
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Krishna takes pleasure when his pure devotees treat him as an equal or treat him as a subordinate."
**Summary:** This segment discusses Krishna's humility in bowing to Yudhishtira, despite being the Supreme Lord, and how He enjoys being treated with love and affection by His devotees, even as an equal or subordinate, contrasting this with the impersonal understanding of Brahman.

In this session we will be discussing from the 8th verse of the 10th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. आमंत्र्यचाभ्यनु ज्ञातः परिश्वज्याभिवाध्यतं आरुरोह रथम् कैश्चित् परिश्वक्तो अभिवाधितः The meaning of this verse is, afterwards, when the Lord asked permission to depart and the king gave it, the Lord offered his respects to Maharaj Yudhishtira by bowing down at his feet. And the king embraced him. After this, the Lord, being embraced by others and receiving their obeisances, got into his chariot. So this was described as the title of the chapter, Departure of Lord Krishna for Dwaraka from Hastinapura. So Krishna, after finishing his work of conducting the battle of Kurukshetra, and installing Maharaj Yudhishtira as the emperor of the world, he was now leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka. Now the description here is that Krishna, even though he is the supreme personality of Godhead, he conducts himself in an ideal manner, setting an example for everyone else, that how the younger ones should show respect to the elders. Krishna is, that is explained by Prabhupada in the purport, Maharaj Yudhishtira was the elder cousin of Lord Krishna. So Maharaj Yudhishtira is elder to Krishna. And therefore, while departing from him, the Lord bowed down at the king's feet. King refers to Yudhishtira. So Krishna is bowing down to Yudhishtira's feet. This is the etiquette, this is the culture. Krishna is younger to Yudhishtira, so therefore he is bowing down. And Yudhishtira, what is Yudhishtira doing? The king, that is Yudhishtira, embraced him as a younger brother. Yudhishtira embraced him. Although, the king knew perfectly well that Krishna is the supreme personality of Godhead. Yudhishtira knows. At the time of Krishna's advent in this world, 5,000 years back, very few people knew Krishna to be the supreme personality of Godhead. Most of them could not recognize him. So, this is another reason why people cannot recognize that Krishna behaves as if he is one among all of us. But then Krishna also performs activities which are extraordinary, which establish his position as the supreme lord. When Krishna is playing with the cowherd boys, it looks like he is one among them. But when there is a war, there is a danger. Some demon comes to attack. Krishna effortlessly kills the demons and dispatches them. So, that killing the demons is not at all an ordinary activity. It's not possible for anyone else to do that. Or lifting the Govardhan hill, that's not possible for anyone to do. Even though he is just a seven-year-old boy, he lifted the Govardhan hill on his little left finger. So, certain activities of Krishna are extraordinary. But if somebody hears about it, they don't have the proper understanding about who is Krishna. They tend to disbelieve it, or they tend to think it is some kind of mythological story. But actually, Krishna is the supreme personality of Godhead. He has unlimited power. So, it is not at all impossible for Krishna to lift the Govardhan hill, or to kill some big demons. But, Krishna also performs activities as if he is an ordinary person. So, here it is being described how the exchange took place when he was leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka. When he was leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka, the Lord took pleasure when some of his devotees accepted him as less important in terms of love. No one is greater than or equal to the Lord, but he takes pleasure in being treated as younger than his devotees. See, this is Krishna's transcendental pastime, that even though those who recognize him, they respect him as the supreme Lord, they offer obeisances always, under all circumstances. Everyone offers obeisances to him as the supreme Lord. But, Krishna takes pleasure when his pure devotees treat him as an equal or treat him as a subordinate. Krishna takes pleasure. So, that is the personal aspect of the Lord. The Lord is the supreme Lord, as a personality. This is the feature of a personality. That they take pleasure or they love something, then it doesn't matter whether etiquette demands something else. So, these are all transcendental pastimes of the Lord, and the impersonalist cannot enter into the supernatural role.

### Eternal relationship with Krishna, Sun and Sun Rays Analogy, Artificial Separation, Molecular parts of Krishna
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5jXUlaUC-oM?t=746
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** analogy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers

**Summary:** The speaker explains the eternal relationship between the living entities and Krishna using the analogy of the sun and its rays, emphasizing that the separation is artificial and due to the influence of material energy.

Why is this so? Prabhupada explains, "Because we are eternally related with Krishna as the sun rays are eternally related with the sun disc. The sun rays are molecular parts of the solar radiation. Thus the sun rays and the sun cannot be separated. Can you have sun rays without sun planet? No. Can you have sun planet without sun planet emanating sun rays? That is also not possible. So the sun rays and the sun planet are always together, always connected. Now there is something called a separation by the cloud, but that separation by the cloud of ourselves and the sun is temporary and artificial, and as soon as the cloud is cleared, the sun rays again display the natural effulgence in the presence of the sun. Similarly, the living entities who are molecular parts of the solar radiation, sorry, the living entities who are molecular parts of the whole spirit Krishna, are separated from the Lord by the artificial energy."

And, when Devaki became pregnant for the seventh time, then that child was transferred by arrangement of Yogamaya, by Krishna's arrangement through Yogamaya, the seventh son of Devaki and Vasudeva was transferred to Rohini's womb, from Devaki's womb. That was Balaram. And, Kamsa thought the seventh pregnancy was a miscarriage. The child died in the womb. That's what Kamsa thought. And then, Krishna appeared as the eighth son in the womb of Devaki, but when Devaki was pregnant for the eighth time, Kamsa was just waiting. Now, this child is going to take birth. I must kill this child as soon as it's born. But, Kamsa could not actually lay his hands on the child, eighth child which is born of the womb of Devaki. Krishna appeared middle of the night by potency of Yogamaya. Kamsa and all the doorkeepers and prison keepers were all asleep under the influence of Yogamaya. And, that is when Vasudeva and Devaki offered wonderful prayers to Krishna when Krishna appeared. And, because they were anxious to protect Krishna, Krishna instructed Vasudeva to transfer him from the prison of Kamsa to the house of Nanda Maharaj and Yashoda, from Mathura to Gokula. And, that's what Vasudeva did in the middle of the night. And, while all this was happening, Kamsa is fast asleep and all his doorkeepers are also asleep. So, this is called Krishna Leela, actually. It's Krishna's pastime.

### Reciprocation, Pure Devotion, Impersonalism
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/RY8k0IEqeEI?t=54
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "He satisfies everyone in terms of one's development of spiritual consciousness."
**Summary:** The lecture begins by explaining how Lord Krishna reciprocates with different types of devotees and admirers, contrasting this with the impersonalists' view of the Absolute Truth.

In this session we will be discussing from the 21st and the 22nd verses of the 11th chapter of 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Bhagavam Stratra Bandhunam Pauranam Anuvartinam Yathavidhi Upasangamya Sarvesham Manam Adadhe. The meaning of this 25th chapter: Lord Krishna, the personality of Godhead, approached them and offered due honor and respect to each and every one of the friends, relatives, citizens, and all others who came to receive and welcome him. So Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, "The Supreme Lord, personality of Godhead, is neither impure nor pure. He is neither impersonal nor an inert object unable to reciprocate the feelings of his devotees. Here the word Yathavidhi, or just as it behooves, is significant. He reciprocates just as it behooves with his different types of admirers and devotees. Of course the pure devotees are of one type only, because they have no other object for service but the Lord. And therefore the Lord also reciprocates with such pure devotees just as it behooves. Namely, he is always attentive to all the matters of his pure devotees. There are others who designate him as impersonal. And so, the Lord also does not take any personal interest. He satisfies everyone in terms of one's development of spiritual consciousness. And a sample of such reciprocation is exhibited here with his different welcomers."

### Absolute Truth, Supreme Person, Liberation
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/RY8k0IEqeEI?t=195
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So when he is the absolute controller, how can that energy which he absolutely controls put him in illusion? That's never possible."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the nature of the Absolute Truth as the Supreme Person with transcendental qualities, contrasting this with the impersonalists' misunderstanding of Krishna's incarnations and emphasizing that the Lord is always liberated.

So, for this explanation we should have the background understanding that the Absolute Truth is ultimately realized as the personality of Godhead, the Supreme Person. And he is having transcendental form, transcendental qualities, transcendental feelings, transcendental activities. Whereas the impersonalists, they refuse to even consider the scriptural description of the Absolute Truth as the Supreme Person. They also wrongly think that when the Supreme Lord incarnates in this world, they think that his form is material, his feelings are material, his personality is material, his personal qualities are all material qualities. And they make the mistake of considering him to be one of the conditioned souls. Whereas the fact is that the Lord is always liberated because it is his energy which conditions everyone else in this material world. So when he is the absolute controller, how can that energy which he absolutely controls put him in illusion? That's never possible. So therefore Srila Prabhupada says that he is neither impersonal nor an inert object unable to reciprocate feelings. And of course his devotees are situated in a proper relationship with him, person to person relationship. And he accommodates all varieties of relationships. He is unlimited personality. He can and he does accommodate all devotees' relationships. Because he is unlimited, he has unlimited devotees. He has unlimited relationships. That's his nature of his personality.

### Vedic culture, role of Brahmanas, glorification of the Lord
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/cdbXzRnv51g?t=53
**Verse References:** SB 1.11.23
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "It is the glorifiers, the brahmanas, who become themselves glorified by glorifying Krishna."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the Vedic culture where Brahmanas offer free service and glorify the king, and how glorifying Krishna benefits the glorifier.

In this session, we will be discussing the 23rd and 24th verses of the 11th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. 23rd verse: स्वयं च गुरुभिर विप्रै सदारै स्थविरैर अपी आशिर्भिर युज्यमानोन्यैर वन्दिभिष्चाविषत्पुरं. The meaning of this 23rd verse: Then the Lord personally entered the city accompanied by elderly relatives and invalid brahmanas with their wives, all offering benedictions and singing the glories of the Lord. Others also praised the glories of the Lord. So, Srila Prabhupada comments on this particular verse in the purport as follows: "The brahmanas in society were never attentive to banking money for future retired life. This is the Vedic culture. The brahmanas always offer free service and even if they get excess of some charity, they spend it off in devotional service. They don't keep money for future. When they were old invalids, they used to approach the assembly of the kings and simply by praising the glorious deeds performed by the kings along with their wives, they would be provided with all necessities of life. What a wonderful society. When they require, they just go and ask the king, and the king will provide. Such brahmanas were not, so to speak, flatterers of the kings, but the kings were actually glorified by their actions." See, they are not doing this just to get some benefit. They are factually glorifying the king for his factual glorious qualities. And here, they are glorifying the supreme king of all kings, the supreme lord, Krishna, who is full of all wonderful qualities. So, the kings, Srila Prabhupada says, were sincerely still more encouraged in pious acts by such brahmanas in a dignified way. The brahmanas would glorify the kings for their good qualities. The kings would also feel encouraged. They would also feel enthused, inspired to do more of such pious activities. In a dignified way, the brahmanas would glorify the king. Lord Sri Krishna is worthy of all glories, and the praying brahmanas and others would glorify themselves by chanting the glories of the lord. In the case of glorification of Krishna, it is not Krishna who is actually in need of the glorification.

---

The meaning of this 24th verse: When Lord Krishna passed over the public roads, all the ladies from the respectable families of Dvārakā, kulaś triyaḥ, went up to the roofs of their palaces just to have a look at the lord. They considered this to be the greatest festival. So Śrīla Prabhupāda elaborately explains this in the purport: "To have a look at the lord is a great festive occasion, undoubtedly, as it was considered by the metropolitan ladies of Dvārakā. This is still followed by the devout ladies of India. Especially during the days of the jhūlan and janmashtami ceremonies, the ladies of India still throng up, in the greatest number, at the temple of the lord, where his transcendental eternal form is worshipped. The transcendental form of the lord installed in a temple is not different from the lord personally. Such a form of the lord is called archa-vigraha, or archa-incarnation, and is expanded by the lord by his internal potency, just to facilitate the devotional service of his innumerable devotees who are in the material world. The material senses cannot perceive the spiritual nature of the lord, and therefore the lord accepts the archa-vigraha, which is apparently made of material elements like earth, wood and stone, but actually there is no material contamination."

### Archa-vigraha, Spiritual nature of the Lord, Material elements
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/cdbXzRnv51g?t=400

So, Śrīla Prabhupāda is comparing that when Kṛṣṇa incarnated, He was received by the ladies of Dvārakā by them going on top of the roofs, and just having the darshan of the lord was like a festival for their eyes, because the lord is very, very, very, very beautiful. And the same facility is available even now in the form of the lord being worshipped in the temple, where he is beautifully decorated, ornamented, and cared for by his devotees. So, this archa-incarnation, worshipable deity form, is not different from the lord personally. It is not an imaginary form, it is not a dead statue. It is actually expanded by the lord's spiritual potency, and it facilitates the devotional service of the devotees. Further, Śrīla Prabhupāda explains, the material senses cannot perceive the spiritual nature of the lord. Therefore, the lord accepts the archa-vigraha, which is apparently made of material elements like earth, wood and stone. See, the archa-incarnation is made of material elements, but that doesn't mean it is a material statue. No. Why? Because the lord is Kaivalya, one alone. There is no matter in him. He is one without a second, and therefore, the almighty lord can appear in any form without being contaminated by the material conception. So when the lord appears in the archa form, he is appearing in his transcendental forms, completely spiritual form. Even though he appears in a material statue, actually he is not contaminated by matter. He is completely spiritual, and his appearance is also completely transcendental. This is difficult to understand for ordinary people, but this is being explained by the āchārya. This is explained in the scriptures.

So we should not imitate Krishna in the matter of Krishna dancing with young gopis in the rasa dance or Krishna lifting Govardhan Hill, don't imitate, but Krishna bowing down, showing respect to all his stepmothers, touching his head to their feet, that is to be followed, that is to be followed. We should show respect to the seven kinds of mothers, including stepmothers, that is to be followed.

And thieves and plunderers and all kinds of rogues, they again go back into hiding because they stealthily try to do all their nefarious activities at night in the darkness. Athavishat Swabhavanam Sarvakamam Anuttamam Prasadayatra Patneenam Sahasranicha Shodasha. The meaning of this verse is, "Thereafter, the Lord entered his palaces, which were perfect to the fullest extent. His wives lived in them, and they numbered over 16." So, Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, Lord Krishna had 16,108 wives, and for each and every one of them, there was a fully equipped palace, complete with necessary compounds and gardens. Full description of these palaces is given in the 10th canto. All these palaces were made of the best marble stone. They were illuminated by jewels, and decorated by curtains and carpets of velvet and silk, nicely bedecked and embroidered with gold lace. These things we can't even imagine in our present yuga. The personality of Godhead means one who is full with all power, all energy, all opulences, all beauties, all knowledge, and all renunciation. That's the meaning of the word Bhagavan—full of six opulences. Therefore, in the palaces of the Lord, there was nothing wanting for fulfilling all desires of the Lord. The Lord is unlimited, and therefore his desires are also unlimited. And the supply is also unlimited. Therefore, his desires are also unlimited.

### Dwarka, Narada's Visit, Krishna's Wives, Opulence
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/cGTQWk7XnhQ?t=176
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "When the great sage Narada heard that Lord Krishna had married 16,000 wives after he had killed the demon Narakasura, Narada was astonished."
**Summary:** The speaker narrates the story of Narada's visit to Dwarka, describing the city's beauty, the palaces of Krishna's wives, and the overall opulence, based on the 10th canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.

Everything being unlimited, it is concisely described here as sarvakamam sarvakamam anuttamam—sarvakamam, full with all desirable equipment. Now, in the 10th canto, there is a beautiful description of the palaces of Krishna. In the 69th chapter of the 10th canto, there is a description. When the great sage Narada heard that Lord Krishna had married 16,000 wives after he had killed the demon Narakasura, sometimes also called Bhamasura, Narada was astonished. The Lord Krishna had expanded himself into 16,000 forms and married these wives simultaneously in different palaces. So, being inquisitive as to how Krishna was managing his household affairs with so many wives, Narada, desiring to see these pastimes, set out to visit Krishna's different homes. So, when Narada arrived in Dwaraka, he saw gardens, and parks full of various flowers of different colors, and orchards overloaded with a variety of fruits. Beautiful birds were chirping, and peacocks crowed delightfully. There were ponds full of blue and red lotus flowers, and some of these tanks were filled with varieties of vegetables, and varieties of lilies. The lakes were full of nice swans and cranes, and the voices of these birds resounded everywhere. In the city of Dwaraka, there were as many as 900,000 great palaces. How many? Nine lakh palaces, built of first-class marble, with gates and doors made of silver. The pillars of the houses and palaces were bedecked with jewels, such as touchstone, sapphire, emerald, and the floors gave off a beautiful luster. Floor giving off luster. Have you ever heard of this? The highways, lanes, streets, crossings, and marketplaces were all beautifully decorated. The whole city was full of residential homes, and streets and also the thresholds of every residential house were very clean. On both sides of every path there were bushes and at regular intervals there were large trees that shaded the avenues so that the sunshine would not bother the passer-by. In this greatly beautiful city of Dwarka, Lord Krishna the Supreme Personality of Godhead had many residential quarters. The great Kings and Princes of the world used to visit these palaces just to worship Lord Krishna. The architectural plans were made personally by Vishwakarma, the engineer of the demigods. And in the construction of the palaces of Lord Krishna, he exhibited all of his talents and ingenuity. These residential quarters numbered more than 16,000.

So first they embraced him within the innermost recesses of their hearts, and then they embraced him visually, and then they sent their sons to embrace him, which is equal to personally embracing him. Now after all this, they tried to restrain their feelings by not shedding tears, but they could not avoid that. They inadvertently shed tears. These are tears of joy on seeing their beloved Lord returned to the past. Those tears, impassioned with his love and respect. This is a very important case for the Lord. So, how can this be fair? You know, Shaunaka and his wife were inside a palace after a long period of absence. So, Srila Prabhupada explains this in the Purport. Although due to feminine shyness, there were many hindrances to embracing the dear husband, Lord Sri Krishna. The Queens performed that act by seeing him through the eyes, by putting him in the course of their hearts. As soon as they saw the impression of the Lord within the core of their heart, these were their instincts, and by sending their sons to embrace him, still the act remained unfinished and tears rolled down their cheeks despite all endeavors to check them. So Srila Prabhupada further explains here, one indirectly embraces the husband by sending the son to embrace him because the son is developed as part of the mother's body. The embrace of the son is not exactly the embrace of husband and wife from the sexual point of view, but the embrace is satisfaction from the affectionate point of view. The embrace of the eyes is more effective in the conjugal relation and thus according to Srila Jeeva Goswami there is nothing wrong in such an exchange of feeling between husband and wife. In this session we will be discussing from the thirty-seventh verse of the eleventh chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: tam ayam manyate loko yasangam api sanginam atmaupamyena manujam vyapruvanam yato abudhaha. The meaning of this verse is, the common materialistic conditioned souls speculate that the Lord is one of them. Out of their ignorance they think that the Lord is affected by matter, although he is unattached. These are words spoken by Srila Suta Goswami. He is speaking to the sages of Naimisharanya. He is describing the Lord. He is describing the transcendental position of the Supreme Lord Krishna. To a common person it may appear like Krishna is an ordinary man because his dealings look like, his dealings with his queens in Dwaraka appears like he is a henpecked husband. But actually Krishna is only reciprocal. He is reciprocating with them because they are his devotees. And he is only attracted by their devotional service. And accordingly Krishna responds with every devotee, every pure devotee. And even while reciprocating with his devotees, even though he may appear to take a subordinate position, his supreme position remains unaffected, because he is the Lord eternally, always, under all circumstances, in all times, at all places, in every situation, in his dealings with everyone.

Everybody can be bewildered by the ashta siddhi displayed by some powerful yogis, perfect yogis. But Krishna is Yogeshwara, the master of all these yogis. They have different kinds of siddhis. But maximum, eight major siddhis and eight minor siddhis, and four auxiliary siddhis. This is explained in detail in the eleventh canto of the Bhagavad Gita. But Krishna personally has unlimited mystic powers. So we cannot even imagine what are the kinds of mystic powers Krishna has. Just like a yogi, to give an example. A yogi can expand into eight forms, at the most, ten forms. Krishna expanded into 16,108 forms when he married 16,108 princesses and was living with them in 16,100 palaces. So that is Krishna, Yogeshwara.

But, Prabhupada explains one important point, for those who are practicing devotional service, whenever you need anything, you ask Krishna only and not anybody else. But, you should also remember, as a supreme Father, the Lord does not supply to a pure devotee what is considered to be a barrier to the discharge of devotional service. So, if we ask in our beginning stages of devotional service from Krishna, something which will block our devotion, then Krishna will not supply that. So, this has to be remembered. Those who are engaged in devotional service of the Lord can rise to the position of unalloyed devotional service. Unalloyed devotional service is pure devotional service, free from any mixture of karma, and material desires, free from all those mixtures. Pure devotional service, we can come to that position by his transcendental attraction. When he attracts us, spiritually. So, by pure devotional service, attraction for Krishna is awakened in the heart. Right on a material condition, we are attracted to so many different material things. That's because of ignorance.

### Krishna's Supremacy, Demigods, Time, Living Entities
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/VXAmI17rayg?t=245

Between Krishna and the other Devata's, between Devata's there is competition, though there is hierarchy among Devata's. But still their position is never permanent. But Krishna's position as the supreme Lord is not a position exactly, it is he who is always the supreme. He is not occupying the post as if the post is sometimes vacant and somebody else may come. No, he is the supreme Lord constitutionally. The influence of time and space is exerted upon the dependent living entities. We are all dependent in this material world. Those are taken birth by force of karma. We depend on the material nature, and there is Kala, powerful Kala, which restricts our duration of life in this body, which limits everything what we can do. Now we as living beings, we are part and parcel of Krishna, but what is our position? The living entities are predominated Brahman. We are spirit, we are spiritual beings, and Lord is spirit, supreme spirit, supremely spiritual being. But we are predominated, we are controlled, we are subordinate to Krishna, whereas the supreme Lord is a predominating absolute. He is always the Lord, the controller, the master, the enjoyer, the supremely powerful. That we have to remember.

Whereas, devotees, they perform actions, they work for Krishna, exclusively for pleasing Krishna. They don't do any material activities. Pure devotees never do any material activities. So therefore, their heart is described as free from the tinge of fructive action. And the second material contamination in the heart is the empirical philosophical speculation. Speculation, you understand, people try to guess or try to conjecture whatever they can't see, whatever they can't perceive, whatever they can't know by direct perception, or even they cannot conceive using the descriptions in the scriptures. They can't relate with it. Then they try to imagine in their mind, by their fertile brain. This is called speculation. And it is philosophical speculation is by taking help of the philosophical descriptions in the scriptures, philosophical descriptions in the scriptures. And empiric is something which is verifiable by material methods. So impersonalists and some of the materialists and some philosophers, material philosophers, all of them indulge in this empiric philosophical speculation, and they think that they can realize the absolute truth or have an understanding of the absolute truth by this method. But the fact is the absolute truth can never be realized by any of such methods, material methods. As long as the heart is contaminated by material contamination, one can never know the absolute truth. It's impossible.

### All-pervasiveness, Consciousness, Krishna's Presence
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/oTyiL8KO0dA?t=495

Unlimited versus limited, the difference. In the Bhagavad Gita, both the living beings and the Supreme Being are said to be all-pervading. That is the description of the Lord. The living being is described as all-pervading, the spirit soul. But, there is a difference between these two. There is a difference between these two kinds of all-pervasiveness. What's the difference? A common living being or soul can be all-pervading within his own limited body. I am present throughout my body. That's why if an ant bites my toe, immediately I come to know, or an ant bites somewhere in my forehead, I immediately come to know. Because, even though I am a very tiny spirit, even though I am a very tiny spirit soul within this body, by my consciousness, I am present everywhere. My consciousness is spread throughout my body. Your consciousness is spread throughout your body. Even Brahma's consciousness is spread throughout his body. But, what about Krishna? What about Krishna's awareness or consciousness? It is spread everywhere: in the spiritual world, in the material world, in every universe, in every planet, in every living being, in every space, in all time. No limitation. The Supreme living being is all-pervading in all space and all time. You see, all space and all time. A common living being cannot extend its influence over another common living being by its all-pervasion. Very simple example: I am within this body. By even using yogic power, I cannot extend my influence over another person's body. Not possible. But the Supreme Supersoul, the Personality of God, is unlimitedly able to exert its influence over all places and all times and over all living beings. See, Krishna enters into the heart of every living being. I have entered into this body. I am situated in this body. Krishna has entered into my body, your body. You are situated in your body. You are not in my body. I am not in your body. Krishna is in your body, my body, everyone's body, everybody.

Nobody is exception. We are very proud of the body that we have, but we don't realize that this body is a prison for the soul, the real I, real self, for me. It is a prison. It is limiting me in so many ways because we do not know as spirit-soul what is the kind of freedom I have. That I do not know. I am totally ignorant of that reality. So, therefore, the scriptures are enlightening us, educating us, informing us, warning us that you are imprisoned in your material body, and it has got a basis. Why? Why are you imprisoned? It is a quack who cheats people, not the learned, enlightened, authorized doctor. So, there is a difference between a quack and a doctor, a good doctor. Similarly, there is a difference between a learned astrologer and a bogus astrologer. There is a big difference and we have to learn that.

**Summary:** The speaker emphasizes the importance of giving charity with purpose, considering the place, time, and recipient, as outlined in the scriptures, and contrasts this with the commercialization of services in Kali Yuga.

Now, the word that is used here, Tirthavit, is significant in this verse because the king, that is Yudhishthira Maharaj, knew well where and when charity has to be given. Yudhishthira Maharaj was aware. He was enlightened. He was Raja Rishi. He was a saintly king. So, he knew when and where charity has to be given. Charity is never unproductive or brutal. Charity has got a purpose. Giving charity is purposefully given, and it is given with due consideration of who is the person who is to be given charity, and when it is to be given, and where should it be given. There are three grades of devotees, namely the Mahabhagavata, Madhyama Adhikari and the Kanishtha Adhikari, three grades. The topmost is the Mahabhagavata, intermediate level of devotion is the Madhyama Adhikari, intermediate level, and Kanishtha Adhikari, the lowest level, the neophyte devotee. Now Srila Prabhupada explains this, three grades of devotees. Those who go to the temples of the Lord and offer worshipful respect to the devotees, the deity, without sufficient knowledge in the theological science, and therefore without any respect for the devotees of the Lord, are called materialistic devotees or Kanishtha Adhikari, the third grade devotees, the lowest, the third grade devotees. Secondly, the devotees who have developed, the second class of devotees, the devotees who have developed a mentality of genuine service to the Lord, and who thus make friendships only with similar devotees, show favor to the neophytes and avoid the atheists, are called the second grade devotees. So the king agreed for that, okay, you want my flesh, I'll give you, but don't kill this pigeon. So he was so generous in giving charity. But now listen what happened. The king began to cut flesh from his body to give a weight of his own flesh equivalent to the pigeon's weight. So there was a balance and one side the pigeon was kept in the balance, other side Shibi's flesh was being put in the balance to match the weight of the flesh that was to be given to this eagle, the hunter bird. But what happened when this weighing was going on, the mystic pigeon always remained heavier. How much ever Shibi was cutting his flesh and putting in the balance in the pan of the balance. So then what did Shibi do? How much will I cut? I myself will sit on the pan. I'll offer my entire body because any amount of flesh I am cutting off and putting it doesn't seem to be balancing the weight of the pigeon. So when he put himself in the balance, I will offer my entire body because any amount of self on the balance to equate with the pigeon, the devatas were pleased with him. So charitable, [he] sacrificed his own life even for the sake of saving the pigeon which has surrendered to him, so protector of the surrendered. So then Indra and Agni disclosed their identity and the king was, Shibi was blessed by them. Devarshi Narada also

So yajña performance by the human beings ensures adequate rainfall, not too much, not too little. **Summary:** The speaker continues the story of Drupada and Dronacharya, focusing on their friendship in Gurukul and Drupada's promise to share his kingdom.

The history is that Drupada and Dronacharya, when they were young students, they studied in the same Guruko, and they were good friends in the Guruko. But this friendship was between the rich son of the rich Kshatriya. Drupada was the son of a very powerful and rich Kshatriya, and Dronacharya was the son of a poor Brahmana. So when Drupada grew up, he became the king of the province called Panchaladesha, very rich. And Dronacharya grew up, but he was just a poor Brahmana's son. So he was another poor Brahmana. Now during the Gurukul days, because they were very good friends, once Drupada, in a, on a certain occasion, he promised to Dronacharya, "When you grow up, don't worry. I will give you half of my kingdom because I am the only son of my father. So I will give you half of my kingdom. Don't worry. You don't have to suffer in poverty like your father." So Dronacharya took these words of Drupada to heart, and he always remembered, even when they went back to their own country, when they went back to their own home after completing the Gurukul education. And Dronacharya was living in utter poverty. So after he got married and he had a son, Ashwatthama, small boy, the boy one day began to cry to his mother that "I have not tasted what is real milk. All my friends say milk is very, very nourishing and very, very tasty and very nice to drink, but I don't know what is milk." So Dronacharya's wife, Ashwatthama's mother, she felt very bad that they were in such poverty stricken condition, that they could not feed their child cow's milk. So she told her husband Dronacharya that "We are so poor. We cannot even feed our child some cow's milk." So Dronacharya said, "Don't worry. I will go to my friend, my friend from Gurukul days, Maharaj Drupada, and I will beg from him in charity a cow. He has promised to give me half his kingdom, but I don't want his wealth in that way, but I will just ask for a cow donation."

### mental equanimity, welfare work, Brahma, Yudhishthira
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/WIdlhURKpCg?t=141
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "In both cases, the comparison is equally good because both of them are recognized representatives of the Supreme Lord."
**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on the comparison of Pariksit to Yudhishthira and Brahma in terms of mental equanimity, explaining their roles in welfare work and how they represent the Supreme Lord.

So Srila Prabhupada has explained little elaborately in the purport how these personalities who are referred to are well known for their specific extraordinary qualities. So Srila Prabhupada says in the purport, mental equanimity refers both to Maharaj Yudhishthira and to Brahma, the grandfather of all living beings. According to Sridhar Swami, one of the commentators on the Bhagavatam, one of the previous Acharyas, the grandfather referred to is Brahma. How is Brahma the grandfather of all of us? Brahma's son, Swayambhuva Manu, that Swayambhuva Manu is the father of mankind. So all human beings have Swayambhuva Manu as their father and Swayambhuva Manu's father is Brahma. Therefore Brahma is the grandfather of all human beings. In that way, Brahma is referred to as the grandfather in this particular comparison, Pitamaha Samaha Samye. And then according to Srila Vishwanachakruti Thakur, another great Acharya, previous Acharya in our Sampradaya, he has written a commentary on the Bhagavatam. Srila Vishwanachakruti Thakur says, the grandfather referred to here is Maharaj Yudhishthira himself. Now Srila Prabhupada says, of course Yudhishthira is the grandfather of Pariksit. Pariksit's father is Abhimanyu. Abhimanyu is the son of Arjuna and Arjuna's brother, Yudhishthira. So therefore Yudhishthira is in the position of the grandfather of child Pariksit. Now Srila Prabhupada says something very interesting. In both cases, the comparison is equally good because both of them are recognized representatives of the Supreme Lord. Both Brahma and Yudhishthira are recognized representatives of the Supreme Lord. Thus both of them have to maintain mental equanimity being engaged in welfare work for the living being.

### Lord Shiva, Vrikasura, benediction, Vishnu, illusion, generosity
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/WIdlhURKpCg?t=575
**Verse References:** —

**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Lord Shiva never denies anyone any sort of gift. He is very liberal."
**Summary:** The speaker continues the discussion of Lord Shiva's generosity with the story of Vrikasura, who received a dangerous benediction from Shiva and was ultimately stopped by Vishnu, highlighting the potential downsides of indiscriminate giving.

Anyone's head simply by touching the head. This is the benediction that Vrikasura asked Shiva: whosoever head I touch, that person's head should immediately get cut off, just by its touch. So Shiva knew that this Asura is going to misuse this benediction. So when Shiva was refusing to give such a horrible benediction, then Vrikasura became very very restless, and he started cutting off the portions of flesh, his own flesh, and offering it to Shiva in sacrifice. So Shiva took compassion upon this foolish Asura and stopped him from killing himself in that way. And then Shiva had to give this stubborn Asura, Vrikasura, the benediction he wanted. Then what did he do? What did this fellow do, this Vrikasura, after he got the benediction? Although Shiva was the one who gave him the benediction, this cunning Asura, he wanted to make an experiment of the power of this benediction by touching the head of Lord Shiva. Thus Lord Shiva had to take shelter of Vishnu to save himself from this trouble. And Lord Vishnu, what did Vrikasura do? When Vrikasura went chasing, then Shiva took shelter of Vishnu and Vishnu confronted this Vrikasura. And by the illusory energy called Yogamaya, Vishnu was able to ask Vrikasura to make an experiment of this benediction by touching his own head. And so, Vrikasura under the illusion, he touched his own head to test whether the benediction is actually working or not. And in this way, Vishnu saved the whole world from the trouble being created by this cunning beggar of the demigods. So, why Prabhupada is narrating all this is because Lord Shiva never denies anyone any sort of gift. He is very liberal. He is therefore the most generous among the givers of benediction. Shiva is the most generous.

It is said in the seventh canto that by severe austerities, this demon Hiranyakashipu satisfied Lord Brahma and obtained the benedictions he desired. Nonetheless, he continued to be envious of Lord Vishnu. He conquered the three worlds. He brought all living entities, both demigods and asuras, under his control. All the demigods except Lord Vishnu, Lord Brahma, and Lord Shiva came under his control and began serving him. Practically, Hiranyakashipu terrorized the whole universe. Since Hiranyakashipu was the oppressor of all the demigods and envious of the Supreme Lord, he would naturally be killed. Hiranyakashipu had four sons, of whom the eldest, Prahlad, was a Mahabhagavata. Hiranyakashipu's spiritual master, Shukracharya, had two sons, Shanda and Amarka. Now, Prahlad Maharaj was entrusted to Shanda and Amarka for education.

In this session we will be discussing from the 34th verse of the 12th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. We will be covering this verse in two parts. So this session will be part 1 of this 34th verse. The verse is as follows: तेन संभृत संभारो धर्मपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरहा वाजिमेधैस् तृभिर्भीतो यज्ञेई समयजद्धरिम्. The meaning of this verse is: By those riches, the king could procure the ingredients for three horse sacrifices. Thus the pious king Yudhishthira, who was very fearful after the battle of Kurukshetra, pleased Lord Hari, the personality of Godhead. So in the previous verse it was described how Yudhishthira Maharaj sent his brothers to fetch wealth for performing this Ashwamedha sacrifice. So they were directed by Krishna to bring some gold, gold which was left behind by the brahmanas who were engaged in sacrifice by a former emperor, Maruth Maharaj. So that gold, Arjuna brought it for Yudhishthira Maharaj to procure ingredients for performing three horse sacrifices. So however good they want to crucify Yudhishthira and take away their wealth through a battle of Kurukshetra, Kanpaksara's desires became as strong as their Councill. So Ripaaprasadana introduced this 2004 shloka here, that Maharaja Yudhishthira was that ideal and celebrated pious king of the world and still he was greatly afraid after the execution of the battle of Kurukshetra, because of the mass killing in the fight, all of which was done only to install him on the throne. Yudhishthira Maharaj is very, very conscientious. He is not comfortable with his acquired position because it involved a killing, mass killing of so many millions of Kshatriyas soldiers. So he was very, very much afraid of the sinful reactions incurred due to such a massacre. He therefore took all the responsibility for sins committed in the warfare and to get rid of all these sins, he wanted to perform three sacrifices in which horses are offered at the altar.

Ashwamedha Yagna or Vajimedha Yagna. Such a sacrifice is very costly. But in the former times, as directed by the Vedic scriptures, people had the spiritual aim of life. And for attaining that ultimate spiritual goal of life, you don't require to have lot of wealth. ### sacrifice, karma, laws of nature, satisfaction of the Lord, peace and prosperity
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/2tKrJn_PZQs?t=692
**Verse References:** BG 3.9
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Therefore, the main purpose of performing sacrifices is to satisfy the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Hari."
**Summary:** This segment explains the importance of performing sacrifices as recommended in the scriptures to counteract sinful reactions and satisfy the Supreme Lord, leading to peace and prosperity.

The Lord says in Bhagavad Gita, yajñārthāt karmano anyatra loko yam karma-bandhanah. In the third chapter, ninth verse, Krishna says this, that one must perform sacrifices recommended in the scriptures in order to get rid of commitments of all unauthorized work or even unintentional crimes which we are apt to commit. Therefore, if one performs the recommended sacrifices, then they are freed from sinful reactions. And those who do not do so, those who do not perform sacrifices, but work for self-interest or sense gratification, such people have to undergo all tribulations accrued from committed sins. The laws of nature are very subtle and they are working perfectly and there is an enforcing authority, material nature itself being directed by the Supreme Lord Krishna. Mayādhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ śūyateśaccharācaram. So, intelligent people understand that any person suffering in this world is only because that person has committed sinful activities for which he is suffering the reactions in the form of miseries, troubles and dangers, diseases and all kinds of, any kind of suffering. Therefore, the main purpose of performing sacrifices is to satisfy the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Hari. The process of performing sacrifices may be different in terms of different times, places and persons. Kāla, Deśa and Pātra. These are Sanskrit words: Time, place and person. But the aim of such sacrifices is one and the same at all times and in all circumstances, namely, satisfaction of the Supreme Lord Hari. Only one aim of performing sacrifices as given in the scriptures, simply to satisfy the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Hari. That is the way of pious life and that is the way of peace and prosperity in the world at large. So, by performing sacrifice for the pleasure of the Supreme Lord Hari, we not only are engaged in pious activity but we are also able to attain peace and prosperity by such performance sacrifices.

Somebody takes up ashtanga, sorry, the method of meditation, the method of cultivating knowledge, etc., then we cannot get more benefit in this way than what is obtained by chanting Hare Krishna in the association of devotees. And by the power of the mantra, the animal which was sacrificed or killed in a horse sacrifice, that animal would be revived when the priest in the sacrifice would actually chant mantras, suitable mantras. And Srila Prabhupada says, there is no possibility of such methodical chanting of the Vedic hymns by the so-called brahmanas who preach of the present age. So therefore, it is recommended to chant the holy name of Supreme Lord Hari, an easy, inexpensive, effective way of doing sacrifice in this age.

The police constables, as usual, arrested all the thieves and Mandukamuni along with them. The magistrates specifically punished the Muni to death by being pierced with a lance. When he was just to be pierced, the news reached the king, and he at once stopped the act on consideration of his being a great Muni. The king personally begged the Muni's pardon for the mistake of his men. And the saint, that is Mandukamuni, at once went to Yamaraj who prescribes the destiny of the living beings. Yamaraj being questioned by the Muni. The king replied that the Muni in his childhood pierced an ant with a sharpened straw and for that reason he was put into difficulty. The Muni thought it unwise on the part of Yamaraj that he was punished for his childish innocence. The Muni thought it unwise on the part of Yamaraj that he was punished for his childish innocence. And thus the Muni cursed Yamaraj to become a Shudra. And thus the Muni cursed Yamaraj to become a Shudra. And this Shudra incarnation of Yamaraj was known as Vidura, the Shudra brother of Dhritarashtra and Maharaj Pandu. And this Shudra incarnation of Yamaraj was known as Vidura, the Shudra brother of Dhritarashtra and Maharaj Pandu. But this Sudra son of the Kuru dynasty was equally treated by Bhishma Deva along with his other nephews, and in due course, Vidura was married with a girl who was also born in the womb of a Sudrani by a Brahmana. Although Vidura did not inherit the property of his father, that is the brother of Bhishma Deva, still he was given sufficient state property by Dhritarashtra, the elder brother of Vidura. Vidura was very much attached to his elder brother Dhritarashtra, and all along he tried to guide him on the right path. During the fratricidal war of Kurukshetra, Vidura repeatedly implored his elder brother Dhritarashtra to do justice to the sons of Pandu, but Duryodhana did not like such interference by his uncle Vidura, and he refused to do so. And thus Duryodhana practically insulted Vidura. This resulted in Vidura's leaving home for pilgrimage and taking instructions from Maitreya.

Dhritarashtra lost all his state and descendants in the fight with Maharaj Yudhishthira, and still due to his sense of helplessness he did not feel ashamed to accept the charity and hospitality of Maharaj Yudhishthira.

### Vidura's birth, Curse of Yamaraj, Lineage of Dhritarashtra and Pandu
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Gz918Ho68hY?t=76
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Vidura, born in the womb of a Shudra woman, was forbidden even to be a party of royal heritage, along with his brothers Dhritarashtra and Pandu."
**Summary:** This segment explains the story of Vidura's birth as the son of a maidservant, his relationship to Dhritarashtra and Pandu, and his resulting lack of inheritance rights.

The meaning of this verse is, as long as Vitura played the part of a Shudra, being cursed by Manduka Muni, Arhyama officiated at the post of Yamaraj to punish those who committed sinful acts. So in the Purport, Shila Prabhupada explains, already it has been told that Vitura was actually Yamaraj. Yamaraj was a Shudra. Yamaraj was cursed due to a small mistake, a slight mistake he did, in carrying out his official responsibility. And he was cursed by Manduka Muni. And therefore, he was born as Vitura in the womb of a Shudra woman. But actually, Prabhupada explains, the real reason why it was actually a higher arrangement by the Supreme Lord, that Yamaraj actually was cursed to take birth like that. So the hidden meaning of this particular incident is very nicely explained by Prabhupada in the Purport. So Shila Prabhupada says, Vitura, born in the womb of a Shudra woman, was forbidden even to be a party of royal heritage, along with his brothers Dhritarashtra and Pandu. If I may refresh your memory about who is Vitura, in terms of his relationship with Dhritarashtra and Pandu, all the three are sons of Vichitravirya, but they are posthumous children. They were born after Vichitravirya's death. And how were they born after Vichitravirya's death? This is called Deva-rena-suton-patti. That means, if a person is unable to conceive children, whatever may be the reason, why such a person, such a person is unable to conceive a child. The emperor of the world, he has to have sons who can succeed him. Qualified, capable, trained up sons. But Vichitravirya died untimely. So then there was nobody to ascend the throne. So then the mother of Vichitravirya, Satyavati, the wife of Shantanu, Vichitravirya's father, he, sorry, Satyavati, she called Vyasadeva and asked for a solution to this problem. So Vyasadeva agreed to impregnate the wives of Vichitravirya, Ampika and Ambalika, two queens. But it so happened that Vyasadeva, even though Vyasadeva was in perfect consciousness, but because he was undergoing severe austerities before he came to impregnate these wives of his brother, Deva and Sutrapati, means conceiving a child by the brother in the womb of one's own wife. So Vyasadeva was the son of Satyavati before her marriage with Shantanu. So Vyasadeva was called upon to impregnate these two queens so that they'll be good progeny for later on occupying the throne. So Dhritarashtra and Pandu were conceived by the two queens, but both of them were not conceived properly. So therefore, in order to conceive a third child, and one of the queens was asked to conceive a third child, but she, instead of conceiving one more child, she asked her maid to go in her place to conceive a child. And that royal maid actually was in very proper consciousness, and therefore, Vyasadeva conceived in that womb of the maiden, a maid servant, Yamaraj, who was cursed to be born as the son of a maid servant. So that was Vidura. So Vidura is actually a step-brother of Dhritarashtra and Pandu. So Dhritarashtra and Pandu were the two sons conceived in the queen. Even though they are conceived by Vyasadeva, they are considered sons of Vichitramirya. All the three are considered sons of Vichitramirya. But the son of the maid servant doesn't have the same position in terms of inheritance like the sons of the queen. So Dhritarashtra and Pandu inherited whatever the royal opulence, but entitled to inherit, but Vidura, as the son of a maid servant, was not entitled for that. So therefore, Srila Prabhupada is saying, Vidura, born in the womb of a Shudra woman, was forbidden even to be a party of royal heritage along with his brothers, Dhritarashtra and Pandu.

### Vidura's authority, Spiritual qualification, Transcendental knowledge
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Gz918Ho68hY?t=476
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Anyone who is conversant in the transcendental knowledge or the science of Godhead, be he a Brahmana or a Shudra...he is a Brahman."
**Summary:** This segment addresses the question of how Vidura, born a Shudra, could instruct learned Kshatriyas, explaining that spiritual qualification and transcendental knowledge are more important than birth.

So the question is being raised, how could Vidura occupy the post of a preacher to instruct such learned kings and Kshatriyas as Dhritarashtra and Maharaj Yudhishtira? If he is the son of a maid servant and he doesn't even have any inheritance, what is his authority to instruct and preach such learned Kshatriyas as Dhritarashtra and Maharaj Yudhishtira? So Srila Prabhupada gives the answer. The first answer is that even though it is accepted that Vidura was a Shudra by birth, because he renounced the word for spiritual enlightenment, by the authority of Rishi Maitreya, and was thoroughly educated by him in transcendental knowledge, he was quite competent to occupy the post of an Acharya, spiritual preceptor. So always the scriptures say, irrespective of birth, if somebody is trained up and has got the qualities of a Brahmana or a Kshatriya or even a Vaisya, even though he may be born in a Shudra family or a Shudra woman, still he is accepted as a Brahmana, Kshatriya or Vaisya according to qualification, training, the qualities he displays, etc. So Vidura was actually Yamaraja himself and even though he was born in the womb of a Shudra woman, he had all the good qualities because of which he was in a position to renounce and seek spiritual enlightenment by Maitreya Rishi and he was also thoroughly educated by Maitreya Rishi in transcendental knowledge. Therefore he was competent to occupy the post of an Acharya or a spiritual preceptor. Now Srila Prabhupada percourses Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. According to Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, anyone who is conversant in the transcendental knowledge or the science of Godhead, be he a Brahmana or a Shudra, a householder or a Sannyasi, kiba vipra kiba nyasi, shudra kenanaya, he Krishna tattva veta, he is a Brahman. If a person is born as a Shudra or if he is a Brahmana or in terms of ashrama, in terms of varana, whether he is a Brahmana or a Shudra doesn't matter. In terms of ashrama, whether he is a householder or a Sannyasi doesn't matter. As long as he is conversant with transcendental knowledge or the science of Krishna consciousness, he is a Brahmana. In terms of Akshara, he is a Brahmana of Krishna consciousness, he is eligible to become a spiritual master.
