### material attachment, illusion, impermanence, shadvikara
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/kMnHa7LYvdc?t=154
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "This is the power of illusion in this material world."
**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on the purport, explaining the symptoms of old age, the concept of 'Shadvikara' (six changes in the body), and how people foolishly seek permanent settlement in the material world, forgetting the impermanence of the body and material possessions.

So in the Purport, Shila Prabhupada explains the symptoms of old age which had already developed in Dhritarashtra were all, one after another, pointed out to him as warning that death was nearing very quickly, and still he was foolishly carefree about his future. The signs pointed out by Vidura in the body of Dhritarashtra were signs of Apakshaya, or dwindling of the material body before the last stroke of death. The body is born, it develops, stays, creates other organs, other bodies, dwindles, and then vanishes. This is called Shadvikara, six different changes that take place in the body from birth to death. So body is born, body is going to die, but in between four stages: body develops, then it stays for some time, produces by-products, and dwindles. So these are described in the Shadvikara. So these are described in the scriptures as Shadvikara, six changes that happen in the body, irrespective of whether it is the body of a small insignificant creature, or the body of a human being, or the body of an animal or a bird, or a demigod, these six changes take place. But foolish men want to make a permanent settlement of the perishable body and think that their estate, their children, their society, country, etc., will give them protection. With such foolish ideas, they become overtaken by such temporary engagements and forget altogether that they must give up this temporary body and take a new one, again to arrange for another term of society, friendship, and love, again to perish ultimately.

In this session, we will be discussing the third and fourth verses of the 13th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. So the third and fourth verses are given together, their translation: "When they saw Vidura return to the palace, all the inhabitants—Maharaj Yudhishthira, his younger brothers, Dhritarashtra, Satyaki, Sanjaya, Kripacharya, Kunti, Gandhari, Draupadi, Subhadra, Uttara, Kripi, many other wives of the Kauravas, and other ladies with children—all hurried to him in great delight. And when Duryodhana, out of foolishness, he insulted Vidura, Vidura left the palace and went away, not because exactly that he was insulted by Duryodhana, but because he was not interested in any material comforts or materialistic way of life. His interest was in Krishna consciousness, and he thought it wise to go on a pilgrimage and travel to holy places, searching for a suitable pure devotee of the Lord to hear Krishna katha and inquire about spirituality from such a bonafide, proper devotee. He inquired from Maitreya Muni, and after he got conviction that the ultimate goal is to be established in transcendental loving service of the Supreme Lord Krishna, after that, he stopped putting questions to Maitreya and returned to Hastinapura.

Kunti Devi was born as the daughter of Maharaj Shurasena, and she was a sister of Vasudeva. Vasudeva was Lord Krishna's father. Later, Kunti was adopted by Maharaj Kunti Bhoja, and hence she is known as Kunti. She was born as the daughter of Maharaj Shurasena, but she was adopted by Kunti Bhoja, and therefore she is called Kunti. She is the incarnation of the success potency of the personality. You got it. The heavenly denizens used from the upper planets used to visit the palace of King Kunti Bhoja, and Kunti was engaged for their reception. In former times, people were very pious, that the pious people of the earth were very strict in following all the rules and regulations, so they were visited by the devatas, and devatas were visible on this earth planet whenever they used to visit here because people were pious. In Kali Yuga, because of the sinful activities having increased too much, we cannot see the devatas even when they come to this material world. Now, whenever these heavenly denizens used to visit King Kunti Bhoja's palace, Kunti was engaged for their reception. She also happened to serve the great mystic sage Durvasa Muni, and being satisfied by her faithful service, Durvasa Muni gave her a mantra by which it was possible for her to call any devata she pleased. As a matter of inquisitiveness, she at once called for the sun god Suryadeva. Now, this Suryadeva, when he was called, he immediately desired couplement with her, but she declined. But the sun god assured her that she would be not adulterated, her virginity would not be adulterated, that she would be given immunity from the adulteration of her virginity. So she agreed to that proposal. As a result of this couplement, she became pregnant, and Karna was born by her. This is before her marriage to Pandu. So by the grace of the sun, she again turned into a virgin girl, but being afraid of her parents, she quitted the newly born child Karna. After that, when she actually selected her own husband, she preferred Pandu to be her husband.

### Vanaprastha, Sanyas, Varna Ashrama, renunciation
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Uel1SCMryu4?t=493
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "These are all based on a very advanced culture and civilization in the Vedic culture."
**Summary:** The speaker explains the stages of Varna Ashrama, focusing on Vanaprastha and Sanyas, and the rules regarding a wife's association with her husband in each stage, highlighting the advanced nature of Vedic culture.

Gandhari decided to follow her husband till the last moment. Maharaj Dhritarashtra accepted the order of Vanaprastha. It is not that after Grahastha, one directly accepts Sanyas. No. Directly accepting Sanyas is possible only for a Brahmachari who decides not to enter the Grahastha Ashrama. Such a Brahmachari can directly accept Sanyas. But a Grahastha, one who has been trained as a Brahmachari and enters Grahastha Ashrama, should next accept Vanaprastha and then accept Sanyas. So, Brahmacharya, Grahastha, Vanaprastha, Sanyas. These are the progressive stages of spiritual development in the life of a civilized, cultured human being following the Varna Ashrama system. But, Dhritarashtra, because he had accepted the Grahastha Ashrama, he next accepted the Vanaprastha order. Now, Srila Prabhupada says, because Dhritarashtra accepted the order of Vanaprastha, at this stage, the wife is allowed to remain as a voluntary servitor of the husband. It is allowed for the wife to remain with the husband as a servitor of the husband. But in the Sanyas stage, no wife can stay with her former husband. So, Sanyas is that particular stage of renunciation or the spiritual order where a Grahastha who renounces home, goes away to the forest or a holy place or to the Himalayas, can take his wife only as long as he is in Vanaprastha order. But Sanyas order, he cannot be with his wife. He has to be away from his wife. Completely away from his wife. Why? Srila Prabhupada explains, according to the scriptures, a Sanyasi is considered to be a dead man civilly. It is declared like he is no longer present for the wife. Therefore, the wife becomes a civil widow without connection with her former husband. These are all based on a very advanced culture and civilization in the Vedic culture. Of course, nowadays it is not practical. Neither it is recommended.

Now, regarding Sanyas, Srila Prabhupada says, briefly, the Sanyasis accept a rod as the sign of the renounced rod of the Danda. Sanyas Danda. Like, I am having this Danda here. So, Sanyasis accept this Danda. What is the significance of this Danda? This Danda is accepted by Sanyasis to signify that they have accepted the renounced daughter of the fly, Sanyas. There are two types of Sanyasis. Those who follow the Mayavadi philosophy headed by Sri Pachankaracharya accept only one rod or Ekadanda, Sanyas. But those who follow the Vaishnava philosophy accept three combined rods called Tridanda. Inside this, three Dandas. There are three rods. The Mayavadi Sanyasis are Ekadandi Swamis, whereas the Vaishnava Sanyasis are Tridandi Swamis. More distinctly, they are called Tridandi Goswamis, in order to be distinguished from the Mayavadi philosophers. The Ekadandi Swamis are mostly fond of the Himalayas. But the Vaishnava Sanyasis are fond of Vrindavan and Puri. Vaishnava Sanyasis generally go to a holy place connected with the pastimes of the Supreme Lord, whereas the Mayavadi Sanyasis they generally go to the Himalayas. The Vaishnava Sanyasis are Narottamas, whereas the Mayavadi Sanyasis are Dheeras. The Vaishnava Sanyasis they from the beginning they learn to depend on Krishna, the Supreme Personality of God. So therefore, specially in Sanyas, they are completely dependent on Krishna only. Where therefore, they are eligible for this Narottama stage of renunciation, the highest stage. Whereas the Mayavadi Sanyasis because they don't have any conception or understanding of the personality of Godhead, so they are mostly Dheeras, undisturbed by material circumstances and detached from all material comforts. So they are mostly Dheeras. So intelligent people simply understand that we have to surrender to Krishna, the Supreme Lord and we have to abide by his laws, orders and pray to him to get out of this entanglement of material existence. Only he can help us cross over this ocean of material existence. Daivihesha gunamayi mamma maya duratyaya ma mevaye prapadyante maya metham tarantite. But if you surrender to Krishna, Krishna will easily help you to cross over and that is what will be explained by Narada.

All around you, you can see this. There is nothing to be lamented if a tiger eats a weaker animal. For its food, a tiger will kill another weaker animal and eat its flesh. Although the law states that a human being must subsist on another living being, there is also the law of good sense. For the human being is meant to obey the laws of the scriptures. For the human beings, there is something extra above the fundamental laws of jivo, jivasya, jivanam. We have to subsist on other living beings, but that doesn't mean that we violate the laws of the scriptures. So we have to live by eating some other living thing, but we also have to follow the laws of scriptures. That is the law of good sense for the human being. The human being is meant for self-realization. And for that purpose, he is not to eat anything which is not first offered to the lord. This is the law of scripture. It is explained in the Bhagavad Gita. Whatever you eat, you have to first offer to Krishna. And only then you are free from reactions. Otherwise, you are going to suffer severe reactions. And what are those reactions? That reaction is called papa.

### supremacy of the Lord, oneness of God, challenges to God
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/f7jFX9_Y1EY?t=55
**Verse References:** SB 1.13.48
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The Supreme Lord Personality of God, it is one without a second."
**Summary:** HH Stoka Krishna Swami introduces verse SB 1.13.48, explaining that Narada Muni is addressing Yudhishthira Maharaj and emphasizing the Supreme Lord is one without a second, illustrating this point with the story of Paundraka who falsely claimed to be God.

In this session we will be discussing from the 48th verse of the 13th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: रदिदं भगवान राजन एक आत्मात्मानं स्वद्रिक अन्तरो अनन्तरो भाती पश्यतं माययो रुधा. The meaning of this verse is: Therefore, O King, you should look to the Supreme Lord only, who is one without a second, and who manifests himself by different energies, and is both within and without. This verse is spoken by Narada Muni, he is addressing Yudhishthira Maharaj. He is explaining the philosophy first and then he is going to give the details about where the two uncles of Yudhishthira, Tritarashtra and Vidura, where have they gone. That is basically Yudhishthira's question to Narada Muni. So Narada Muni is going to answer that, before that he explains the philosophical basis for the solution to Yudhishthira's problem. And already Narada Muni has explained that when our own body is under the clutches of material nature, how can we help somebody else who may be suffering or undergoing difficulty because of their bodies being under the clutches of material nature. So it is ultimately the Supreme Lord, who is the Supreme Controller, who actually is the ultimate cause of all causes. We have to look towards him only after we do our duties. It is not that we neglect our duties because Supreme Lord is in control. No, we have to do our duties, but beyond that we only look towards the Lord. And Srila Prabhupada explains this in the purport very elaborately. Srila Prabhupada says, "The Supreme Lord, Personality of Godhead, is one without a second." That means he is the only one who is the Supreme Lord. There are no two Supreme Lords, only one. Supreme means one, and there is nobody else who is a competitor to God. Sometimes we hear that somebody else is challenging God. That is never possible. It never has happened, never will happen. Even when Krishna was present on this earth, he had incarnated 5000 years ago, he was in Dwaraka. One Asura by name Paundraka, he declared himself as the real God, and he told Krishna, he challenged Krishna that you give up your symbols because I am the real Vasudeva. And Krishna actually when he received that note from the messenger of this Paundraka, Paundraka was a king ruling a particular province, and this Paundraka declared himself to be God. And this happens even now, that somebody declares I am God. So these sort of claims have no real foundation, they have no real basis. So Krishna just sent his Sudarshan Chakra. The Sudarshan Chakra cut off this Paundraka's head, and that was the end of Paundraka. So these sort of claims have no real basis. Therefore it is very clearly said by Narada, authoritative statement, the Supreme Lord, Personality of God, it is one without a second.

So this manifestation here means everyone here has got a material body, and that material body is not only externally covering the soul, but the consciousness also has become polluted by the material atmosphere with a false sense of identity, as I am independent, I am the Lord, I am the master, I am the enjoyer, I am the proprietor. All these contaminations are even there in the consciousness. So that's why Srila Prabhupada says here, "The living being is pervertedly manifested in this material world, and therefore he experiences so called happiness and distress in the material world." What is our original position? Completely blissful, eternally in the association of Krishna in the spiritual world. That is our original position, that's our pure state of existence. But this contaminated state in the material world is such that there is illusory happiness and there is illusory distress. Such experiences are all ephemeral. Ephemeral means they are all temporally manifested and do not affect the spirit soul. The spirit soul is completely aloof from all the material coverings or the material influence. The perception of such ephemeral happiness and distress is due only to the forgetfulness of its qualities. We forget our own spiritual quality. In contact with this material nature, we forget our self, we forget our spiritual nature.

In this session we will be discussing from the 49th verse of the 13th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, सोयम अध्यमहाराज भगवान भूतभावनह कालरूपो अवतीरणो स्याम अभावाय सुरत्विशाम। The meaning of this verse is, that supreme personality of Godhead, Lord Sri Krishna, in the guise of all devouring time, कालरूपा, has now descended on earth, to eliminate the envious from the world. So, this verse describes Krishna's descent, also as the all devouring time, कालरूपो. So, Prabhupada explains this in the purport. There are two classes of human beings, namely the envious and the obedient, who are called the envious. Since the supreme lord is one and the father of all living beings, the envious living beings are also his sons, but they are known as the asuras. But the living beings who are obedient to the supreme father are called devatas or demigods, because they are not contaminated by the material conception of life. Demigod means almost like God, or godly. Demigods also can be called godly persons or godly beings. Not only are the asuras envious of the lord, in even denying the existence of the lord, but they are also envious of all other living beings. See, this is the nature of the asuras. It's called demoniac nature. This is described in the Bhagavad Gita also, 16th chapter. The demoniac nature and the divine nature. The predominance of asuras in the world is occasionally rectified by the lord when he eliminates them from the world and establishes a rule of devatas like the Pandavas. The lord sometimes personally comes and sometimes he deputes his devotee. To kill these asuras and establish the proper rule of the devatas, like the Pandavas, godly beings. So his designation, that means the lord's designation as Kala in disguise, is significant. Kalaropoyam. He is not at all dangerous, but he is the transcendental form of eternity, knowledge and bliss. Kalaropoyam. That's the real form of the Supreme Lord. Full of bliss, full of knowledge. Very, very beautiful form, most attractive and very pleasing to the eyes. So that is the real form, original form of the lord. But, Prabhupada says, for the devotees, his factual form is disclosed, and for non-devotees, he appears like Kalarupa, which is causal form. So what is the causal form? This causal form of the Lord is not at all pleasing to the asuras. When he appears as death, that is not at all pleasing to anybody.

And become imitation lords of all they survey. This is the whole disease. It is called Bhavaroga, material disease. And this is only possible with material association. It is not possible in the spiritual existence. Everyone is trying to become an imitation god. We cannot be. We cannot become god. We can try to imitate god. That's what all these Asuras do. They declare there is no god, or I am god, or everyone is god. All these kind of foolish things are done by Asuras only, not by the demigods. There is a keen competition among such imitation gods and such competitors are generally known as Asuras. Even the Asuras sometimes they fight among themselves. One tries to kill the other or one tries to overpower the other. When there are too many Asuras in the world, then it becomes a hell for those who are devotees of the lord. Devotees want to live peacefully doing their own devotional service. They have no desires like the Asuras. But these Asuras become too many in number. The Asuras disturb the devotees also. Due to the growth of the Asuras, both of the Asuras, the mass of people who are generally devoted to the lord by nature, and the pure devotees of the lord, including the demigods in higher planets, pray to the lord for relief. And when the devatas, devotees pray to the lord, then what happens? The lord either descends personally from his abode or deputes some of his devotees to remodel the fallen conditions of human society, or even animal society. The lord can appear in any form, but he remains the transcendental lord and his form is always spiritual, though it appears like a material form. It is not a material form. Such disruptions take place not only in human society, but also among animals, birds or other living beings, including the demigods in the higher planets.

In this session we will be discussing from the 54th verse of the 13th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. जितासनो जितश्वासह प्रत्याहृतशड़िन्द्रियह हरिभावनया ध्वस्त रजसत्वतमो मलहा The meaning of this verse is, one who has controlled the sitting postures, the yogic asanas, and the breathing process, can turn the senses toward the absolute personality of Godhead, and thus become immune to the contaminations of the modes of material nature, namely mundane goodness, passion, and ignorance. So, Narada Muni is describing. How does that work? In the Ashtanga Yoga system, which is practiced by those who follow this Ashtanga Yoga process, how does it work? So, here, जितश्वासह, जितासनो जितश्वासह, जितासनो is controlled sitting postures. Because, unless a yogi is able to sit properly, he cannot become completely absorbed in meditation. He'll be disturbed by the body. So, this practice of yogasana, different sitting postures, or different bodily exercises, for controlling the sitting posture, the ability to sit, for a very, very long time, without any distraction, without any disturbance. Then, जितास्वासह, the breathing process, also has to be controlled. Why the breathing process has to be controlled? To turn the senses toward the absolute personality of Godhead, and thus become immune to the contaminations of the modes of material nature. We are influenced by the three gunas. So, that influence is felt through the senses, through the mind, through our material activities. We feel the influence, we experience the influence. Sometimes, we are influenced by goodness, sometimes by passion, sometimes by ignorance. So, a combination of these modes always acts, in most cases. In any case, these influences, are material influence. They are all the influence of the material energy. Because, the material energy consists of these three gunas. Sattvam rajas tamaiti guna prakati sambhavah. Prakati sambhavah. They are the ingredients of this material nature, these three gunas. And, they influence the body. They influence the living being in this material world. One has to become free from these influences. And, that we described here. The purpose, Srila Prabhupada says, the preliminary activities of the way of yoga are asana, pranayama, pratyahara, dhyana, dharana, etc. Eight steps are there. Maharaja Dhritarashtra was to attain success in those preliminary actions. Because, he was seated in a sanctified place. And, was concentrating upon one objective. What is that one objective? Namely, the supreme personality of Godhead, Hari. So, real yoga practice means, to focus or concentrate one's attention on the supreme Lord who is seated in everyone's heart. The Lord is there. And, everybody's heart he has entered. sarvasya caaham rudhi sannyavishto mattasmrutir jnanam appohanam jnanam In the fifteenth chapter, Krishna says, I am seated in everybody's heart. In the eighteenth chapter also, Krishna explains, ishwaras sarvabhutanam hrudeshe aryoh deshtati The supreme Lord is seated in everyone's heart. And, he is seated as Paramatma. Upadrishta anumanta bharta bhokta maheshwaraha Paramatmeti chaapyukto dehesmin purusha paraha There is a transcendental enjoyer, the supreme Lord as Paramatma. Paramatma iti uktaha He is called as Paramatma. He is not Atma. He is Paramatma. He is supreme Atma. Supreme soul. Super soul.

### Srimad Bhagavatam, chronology, questions and answers
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/gU44V7gUdck?t=46
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "No, the sequence of description in the Bhagavatam follows the questions and answers, the questions and the answers."
**Summary:** The speaker introduces Chapter 14 of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining that the Bhagavatam's structure is based on questions and answers rather than strict chronological order, emphasizing the importance of the message.

We are going to begin a new chapter, chapter 14 of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. The chapter is entitled, "The Disappearance of Lord Krishna." This is the speciality of the Bhagavatam. Bhagavatam topics are not necessarily chronologically described. Chronologically means first this happened, then this happened, then something else happened, then something else happened, then something else happened. No, the sequence of description in the Bhagavatam follows the questions and answers, the questions and the answers. So, according to the question being asked, the answer is given. And the answer is given with support of the historical incidents, describing certain incidents, describing certain important principles illustrated in the life of great devotees or taught by the activities of the Supreme Lord in his various incarnations, etc. So, the disappearance of Lord Krishna is described in the first canto. The appearance of Lord Krishna is described in the tenth canto. This is the peculiarity of the Srimad Bhagavatam. And not only Bhagavatam, even the other Puranas also, there is description of different topics according to the questions raised and according to the sequence in which the answers are given to questions, questions as the questions are raised and the message is important even if one is not able to strictly follow the chronology, the sequence of events very strictly important.

**Summary:** The speaker discusses the Vedic science of Nimitta, differentiating between auspicious and inauspicious signs, and emphasizing the scriptural basis for recognizing omens, distinguishing it from superstition.

So he is telling Bhima about the bad omens that he is observing. So, in the purportional pravapa says just one sentence, these are some bad omens indicating something undesirable in the near future. There is a science in the Vedic literature called science of nimitta. Nimitta means certain indications by which we can say we can expect something auspicious to happen, or some other indications which indicate to us that something inauspicious is going to happen. So, in this material world, there is always consideration of auspicious symptoms and inauspicious symptoms. In the spiritual world, there is all auspiciousness; there is no inauspiciousness. So, this difference always exists between the material world and the spiritual world. Besides that, this science of Nimitta is not some superstitious belief as sometimes people may think. Modern man thinks that if the scriptures describe the crying of the she-jackal is inauspicious at the time of the rising of the sun, then people may dismiss it as something superstitious. Well, some people do have some superstitious beliefs which are not based on scriptures, that is all right. But if the scriptures are informing us of some inauspicious happenings, that we can expect undesirables in the near future by some bad omens, and they are very specific. It is not that I think it is bad or somebody else thinks it is not so bad. No, it is actually universally true, these bad omens. So, some of these bad omens are being observed by Yudhishthira and he is indicating them to Bhima.

### Vishnu Tattva vs. Jiva Tattva, Dependence on Krishna, Protection of the Lord
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/6y1C9X5o-wE?t=696
**Verse References:** BG 4.8
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Dependence on Krishna. That is the best dependence."
**Summary:** This segment differentiates between Vishnu Tattva and Jiva Tattva, emphasizing the dependence of Jiva Tattva on Krishna for protection and the eternal servitude of liberated souls.

As stated in the Bhagavad Gita, 4th chapter, 8th verse, The Lord and His eternal associates, who are also liberated souls like the Lord, come down on this earth at certain intervals. The Lord remembers them all but His associates, although liberated souls, do not forget, due to their being tatastha shakti or marginal potency of the Lord. Just like in the 4th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita it is said, Arjuna, he forgot that he had appeared with Krishna several times before. He had forgotten that, whereas Krishna remembers all of them. And that is very clearly explained in the 4th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita. That is the difference between the Viṣṇu Tattva and Jīva Tattva. We belong to Jīva Tattva. Krishna, Vāsudeva, Sankarsana, Pradyumna, Aniruddha, Narayana, Balarāma, Rāma, Narsimha, Varāha, all belong to Viṣṇu Tattva. They never forget anything, whereas we Jīva Tattva, we forget because of our tiny positioning. The Jīva Tattvas are infinitesimal potential particles of the Lord, and therefore they require the protection of the Lord at all times. And to the eternal servitors of the Lord, the Lord is pleased to give all protection at all times. The Lord is very pleased to give protection, and that is our position, dependence. Dependence on whom? Dependence on Krishna. That is the best dependence. That is eternal protection, dependence on Krishna. The liberated souls never therefore think themselves as free as the Lord. The Lord is completely free, completely independent, and the liberated souls, even though they are free from the touch of matter, they don't think themselves independent. They always seek the protection of the Lord in all circumstances, in the material world and in the spiritual world. In the spiritual world there is no question of seeking protection, but their attitude is, I want to be eternally under Krishna's shelter, Krishna's protection. This is the attitude of all devotees, all liberated souls.

### Constitutional Dependence, Spark and Fire Analogy, Spiritual Ignorance
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/6y1C9X5o-wE?t=857
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** analogy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "This dependence of the liberated soul is constitutional."
**Summary:** This segment uses the analogy of a spark and fire to illustrate the constitutional dependence of liberated souls on Krishna, warning against spiritual ignorance and the dangers of seeking independence from the Lord.

Now Srila Prabhupada explains a very important point. This dependence of the liberated soul is constitutional, for the liberated souls are like sparks of a fire that are able to exhibit the glow of fire along with the fire and not independently. This is the best example that can help us understand what is our active position. A spark of a blazing fire is very, very insignificant, tiny. But as long as the spark is in the fire, it will glow, like the fire. But the spark cannot independently glow when it is separated from the blazing fire. Independently, the glow of the spark is extinguished, although the quality of fire or the glowing is there, as spirit-soul. Our quality of spirit is actually not exhibited when we are separated from Krishna. Those who give up the protection of the Lord and become so-called Lords themselves, out of spiritual ignorance, come back again to the material world, even after prolonged tapasya of this severe type. That is the verdict of all Vedic literature.

These are all different reasons why a respectable personality becomes very depressed or dejected or very unhappy. So Yudhishthira is trying to find out what is the cause for Arjuna's dejection. So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "A kshatriya or a rich man is sometimes visited by persons who are in need of money. When they are asked for a donation, it is a duty of the possessor of wealth to give charity in consideration of the person, place, and time. If a kshatriya or a rich man fails to comply with this obligation, he must be very sorry for this discrepancy. Similarly, one should not fail to keep his promise to give in charity. These discrepancies are sometimes causes of despondency, and thus, failing, a person becomes subjected to criticism, which might also be the cause of Arjuna's plight," Yudhishthira is trying to guess. So one should never go back on one's promise made to somebody to give charity; that is a very important culture. And if somebody does default, then there is such a problem. The person is subject to criticism. So Arjuna is being questioned by Yudhishthira, "Did you undergo any humiliation like that?"

### Caste system, Respect for women, Seven mothers, Uttama and Adhama contact
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/PAiiSnmCzoE?t=233
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The wife of a Brahmana is considered one of the seven mothers."
**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on the Vedic social structure, explaining the rules regarding contact between men and women of different castes, emphasizing the respect due to certain women, particularly the wife of a Brahmana.

So Srila Prabhupada explains this further. The higher caste men, namely the Brahmanas and Kshatriyas, could accept a woman of the Vaishya or the Shudra community. But a man from the lower caste could not contact a woman of the higher caste. Even a Kshatriya could not contact a woman of the Brahmana caste. Why? Why is this so? That is explained by Prabhupada in the next sentence of this purport. The wife of a Brahmana is considered one of the seven mothers. This is a Vedic conception. There are seven mothers who are all respectable by everyone. Who are the seven mothers? One's own mother, the wife of the spiritual master or teacher, the wife of a Brahmana, the wife of a king, the cow, the nurse, and the earth. We say mother earth, mother cow. So these are the seven mothers in the Vedic conception of mother. And mother means everyone respects, everyone offers respect. So therefore, that is the reason a Kshatriya could not contact a woman of the Brahmana caste. This we are talking about openly mixing. That is not allowed. Out of respect. It is not a question of curtailing some freedom. No. It is out of respect. Please understand this point. Such contact between man and woman was known as uttama or adhama. Contact of a Brahmana with a Kshatriya woman is uttama. But the contact of a Kshatriya with a Brahmana woman is adhama and therefore condemned.

### Grihasta Dharma, Vedic Culture, Social Responsibility
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/UmR2yfB8dDI?t=54
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So grihasta dharma is very very very important for upkeep of the society for the spiritual upkeep of the society."
**Summary:** This segment explains the duties of a Grihasta (householder) in Vedic society, emphasizing their responsibility to provide for children, the elderly, Brahmanas, invalids, and even unknown hungry individuals.

In this session, we will be discussing from the 43rd and 44th verses of the 14th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. These are the last two verses of this chapter. This chapter is entitled, "The Disappearance of Lord Krishna." The 43rd verse: अपिसित परियभुं तास्त्वं संभोज्यान वृद्धबालकान जो परियभुं तास्त्वं संभोज्यान वृद्धबालकान जुगुप्सितं कर्म किञ्चित् कृतवान नयद अक्षमं. The meaning of this verse is, "Have you not taken care of old men and boys who deserve to dine with you? Have you left them and taken your meals alone? Have you committed some unpardonable mistake which is to be considered abominable?" This question itself indicates how very exalted was the Vedic culture, that the consideration always for a person before he takes his food, especially lunch, is that he feeds all those who are desirous of food and he is deserving to be fed by a grihasta. This is called grihasta dharma. In the Vedic society, the four spiritual orders: brahmachari, grihasta, vanaprastha, sannyas. Out of these four orders, the grihasta has got certain duties which is absolutely essential to be carried out by the grihasta for the upkeep of the other three spiritual orders. A brahmachari goes and begs from householders. A vanaprastha, he also, of course a vanaprastha does not really beg from a grihasta, but a vanaprastha may beg from a grihasta if he cannot get anything in the forest in terms of fruits, roots, berries or something edible like that in nature. And a sannyasi, of course, he travels from door to door to enlighten people, but in the pretext of begging he tries to approach householders to enlighten them spiritually. So for his subsistence he may take a little, some, bare minimum bhiksha, some food, that's it! So grihasta dharma is very, very, very important for upkeep of the society, for the spiritual upkeep of the society. So Yudhishthira is asking Arjuna that have you not taken care of old men and boys who deserve to dine with you? So Prabhupada explains in the purport, it is the duty of a householder to feed first of all the children, the old members of the family, the brahmanas and the invalids. Such a wonderful culture it is, the very culture, the duty of the householder to feed these four categories of persons. Who are they? The children, the old members of the family, the elderly people, the brahmanas and the invalids. The brahmanas don't work for earning money or for their own maintenance, they don't work. They just give spiritual guidance to the entire society, rest of the society, after themselves becoming well versed in the scriptural knowledge. So they give free consultation to anybody in any subject matter free of charge and for the service they give to the society they are maintained by the other members of the society, especially householders. So householders they share what they have with brahmanas and the invalids. Due to some reason somebody is not able to work and earn money or get their livelihood then they are maintained by the others who are capable of earning and generating wealth. Those able bodied persons should maintain the invalids. This is the culture.

### Charity, Hospitality, Vedic Injunctions, Grihasta Dharma
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/UmR2yfB8dDI?t=379
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Any householder before he takes his meals he should go out of his house after having fed all these people children, old members of the family, the brahmanas and the invalids after having fed them before he takes his own meals he goes out and calls three times is there anybody hungry who needs food anyone they can come and actually they will be fed first before the grahastha himself takes his meals he will feed them if any unknown hungry man they won't even ask who are you no questions asked you are hungry at lunch time please take prasad this is the culture."
**Summary:** This segment elaborates on the Vedic injunction for householders to offer food to any hungry person before taking their own meals, illustrating this principle with a story and highlighting the importance of this practice.

So Prabhupada says further, besides that, an ideal householder is required to call for any unknown hungry man to come and dine before he himself goes to take his meals. Any householder before he takes his meals he should go out of his house after having fed all these people, children, old members of the family, the brahmanas and the invalids, after having fed them, before he takes his own meals he goes out and calls three times, "Is there anybody hungry who needs food?" Anyone, they can come and actually they will be fed first before the grahastha himself takes his meals. He will feed them if any unknown hungry man, they won't even ask who are you, no questions asked, you are hungry at lunch time please take prasad. This is the culture, this is the chastric injunction. So a grahastha, a householder is required to call for such a hungry man thrice on the road. In fact, I have heard this that even now in some provinces there are people who follow this injunction. I know of a certain gentleman who said he was travelling in Karnataka in the south canada district, he was going from one place to another place by his car and while he was passing through one particular village it was about lunch time, say one o'clock in the afternoon and his car was stopped by a gentleman of the village and he stopped the car and he was curious why did that gentleman stop his car. So the gentleman said, "I am from this village. I stopped you to inquire from you, have you had your lunch?" So this person in the car said, "No I have not had my lunch." "Please come to my house for lunch," he invited. So this is grahastha dharma. So then that person in the car said who is travelling, who is a traveller, he was very pleased and he went to that gentleman's house of the village and took his meals. So formerly there were no hotels, there were no restaurants either. People would go to a temple which had the arrangement of feeding any visitors at lunch time. Even now if you go to Udupi temple you will get, you will get lunch at lunch time or if you go to ISKCON Bangalore temple you can get lunch at lunch time. So like this there are still some temples even in north India, even in south India, even in Gujarat, in Rajasthan, in Bengal, in Bihar, in Orissa, there are temples which feed people who are visitors in the afternoon at lunch time and sometimes the householders will to a limited extent they may host a person who is a visitor or a traveller or a person who has no arrangement for cooking his food, they may host such a person and feed him. So this is what is explained by Prabhupada here, the neglect of this prescribed duty of a householder especially in the matter of the old men and children is unpardonable. It is considered as a violation of the Vedic injunction for a householder who does not feed such deserving people. So Yudhishthira's question to Arjuna is, did you refuse to feed such deserving people, refuse to feed somebody who was worthy of being fed as a grahastha dharma?

### Separation from Krishna, Dejection, Spiritual Loss, Yudhishthira's Inquiries
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/UmR2yfB8dDI?t=646
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Or is it that you are feeling empty for all time because you might have lost your most intimate friend Lord Krishna O my brother Arjuna I can think of no other reason for your becoming so dejected."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the 44th verse, focusing on Yudhishthira's inquiry into Arjuna's dejection and suggesting that it stems from the separation from Lord Krishna, referencing Narada's earlier indication of Krishna's departure.

You didn't do your duty because of which you are dejected. The 44th verse, the last verse: कचित् प्रेष्ठतमॆनाथा हृदयेनात्म बन्धुना शुन्योस्मि रहितो नित्यं मन्यसेते अन्यथा नरुक. The meaning of this verse is, "Or is it that you are feeling empty for all time because you might have lost your most intimate friend Lord Krishna? O my brother Arjuna, I can think of no other reason for your becoming so dejected." So Srila Prabhupada says in the purport, "All the inquisitiveness of Maharaj Yudhishthira about the world situation was already conjunctured by Maharaj Yudhishthira on the basis of Lord Krishna's disappearance from the vision of the world and this is now disclosed by him because of the acute dejection of Arjuna which could not have been possible otherwise." So even though he was doubtful about it he was obliged to inquire frankly from Arjuna on the basis of Sri Narada's indication. If you recollect in the previous chapter, Dhritarashtra quits home, it was indicated by Narada to Yudhishthira that you Pandavas, you remain on the earth as long as Krishna is on the earth and after Krishna's departure you also may leave this world. So Krishna's departure was hinted by Narada when Yudhishthira had inquired from Narada about Dhritarashtra's quitting home. So this was in the back of the mind of Yudhishthira. So he sent Arjuna after that to inquire from Krishna what is the future program of Krishna and Arjuna did not return for seven months. So Yudhishthira became very anxious whether Krishna has departed from this world because of which so many bad omens were being seen by Yudhishthira and those were described in the beginning of this chapter. So now Yudhishthira is directly inquiring from Arjuna, are you feeling so dejected because you have lost your most intimate friend Lord Krishna because Krishna has departed for the spiritual world, Krishna is no longer on this earth planet. So Yudhishthira is even concluding, "I can think of no other reason for your becoming so dejected," and it will turn out that in the next chapter it will be described how Arjuna replies to all these questions with one answer to begin with and later on he recollects how he is feeling separation from Krishna because Krishna has departed for the spiritual abode, for the spiritual abode after winding up his pastimes. So that is what Arjuna is going to reply but Yudhishthira has already figured out by Arjuna not answering in the affirmative for any of the other reasons for Arjuna's dejection. He has denied, "I am not dejected because of all the other reasons that Yudhishthira thought could be the reason for Arjuna's dejection."

So everyone began to speak of Haridasa Thakur's great qualities. So the brothers were very happy to hear everyone glorifying Haridasa Thakur. ### Krishna's mercy, satisfaction, universal connection
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/9hE7nn0Xp4k?t=574
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers

**Summary:** The speaker narrates how Krishna ate a tiny grain from the pot, satisfying everyone, including Durvasa Muni and his disciples, highlighting the universal connection through Krishna.

So, when she was unable to give any food to Krishna, she began to cry, as is natural for a woman who is in difficulty. But, when she began to cry, Krishna called her and said, Why don't you bring that pot which has been gifted by the Sun God to you? Bring that pot now, immediately. So, Draupadi brought that pot. The pot was empty. The pot was not having any food. So then, Krishna examined very carefully inside the pot. There was one small grain of foodstuff sticking to a corner of the pot. So, Krishna picked up that small grain and ate it immediately. After Krishna had taken that one small grain remaining in the pot, he told Draupadi, Now, you can invite your guests and you can feed them. So, on Krishna's instruction, Draupadi went to Yudhishthira and told him, Now, the guests can be invited. So, Yudhishthira sent Bhima to the river to call Durvasamuni and his 10,000 disciples to come for lunch. And meantime, what had happened, that Durvasamuni and his disciples were taking bath in the river and performing their religious duties. They began to feel completely satisfied, completely satisfied. Their hunger was completely mitigated. That, when Bhima came to invite them, Durvasamuni thought, Oh, Yudhishthira should have arranged a big feast and I am feeling very much full. How can I do justice? I better don't go. I don't accept that invitation because I am already feeling completely full in my stomach, in my belly, just by taking this bath. Though actually, Durvasamuni had not taken his meals at all that day, but still he began to feel full. So, since Durvasamuni thought that he didn't want to disappoint Yudhishthira by refusing outright the lunch, so he quietly went away from that place without going to Yudhishthira's camp. He and his disciples all felt completely full and they went away. Now, how is it that without eating anything, actually the 10,000 disciples of Durvasamuni and Durvasamuni himself began to feel full? It is because yasmintushte jagatushtihi When Krishna is satisfied, everyone is satisfied. When Krishna's hunger is mitigated, everyone's hunger is mitigated.

### Demigods vs. Supreme Lord, Devotion to Krishna, Srila Prabhupada's purport
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/bgJl9llMpcc?t=124
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "By such a conception one becomes an offender ultimately meets with the same end as Ravana and others."
**Summary:** The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's purport, emphasizing that pleasing the Supreme Lord Krishna is superior to pleasing demigods, and that devotees of Krishna respect demigods, but those who consider demigods equal to Krishna are offenders.

These are words spoken by Arjuna. He is speaking to Yudhishthira. He has returned from Dwaraka. He has brought the news that Krishna has departed for his personal abode. And he is recollecting the grace of Lord Krishna, by which he was able to do so many wonderful things. So Srila Prabhupada explains this in the purport: By the grace of the Supreme Personality of God, Sri Krishna, all the demigods including Lord Shiva were pleased with Arjuna. The idea is that one who is favored by Lord Shiva or any other demigod may not necessarily be favored by Arjuna. But he was certainly a great devotee of Lord Shiva, but he could not be saved from the wrath of the Supreme Personality of God, Lord Ramachandra. And there are many instances like that in the histories of the Puranas. But here is an instance where we can see that Lord Shiva became pleased even with the grace of Lord Shiva. He was pleased with Arjuna. Even in the fight with Arjuna. The devotees of the Supreme Lord know how to respect the demigods, but the devotees of the demigods sometimes foolishly think that the Supreme Personality of Godhead is no greater than the demigods. By such a conception one becomes an offender, ultimately meets with the same end as Ravana and others. The instances described by Arjuna during his friendly dealings with Lord Sri Krishna are instructive for all who may be convinced by the lessons that one can achieve all favors simply by pleasing the Supreme Lord Sri Krishna, whereas the devotees or worshippers of the demigods may achieve only partial benefits which are also perishable, just as the demigods themselves are.

### Krishna's plan, Devotee's surrender, Divine arrangement
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/IYLnVLjobeg?t=530
**Verse References:** SB 1.15.20
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "In order to keep the words of the great Muni, the Lord himself kidnapped his wives from the protection of Arjuna."
**Summary:** The speaker explains the apparent contradiction in verse 20, where Arjuna is defeated and Krishna's wives are kidnapped, by narrating a story from the Vishnu Purana and Brahma Purana about a curse and Krishna's arrangement to fulfill it.

The meaning of this verse is, "O Emperor, now I am separated from my friend and dear most well-wisher, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, and therefore my heart appears to be void of everything. In his absence, I have been defeated by a number of infidel, and I have heard men while I was guarding the bodies of all the wives of Krishna." After Krishna's disappearance, this was an incident that took place that Arjuna was taking charge of protecting the wives of Krishna and something happened that is very bewildering when we hear that some infidel, coward men, they defeated Arjuna and actually kidnapped the wives of Krishna. So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains this point. The important point in this verse is how it was possible that Arjuna could be defeated by a gang of ignoble, coward men and how such mundane, coward men could touch the bodies of the wives of Lord Krishna who are under the protection of Arjuna. So Srila Vishwanachakravarti Thakur, one of our previous Acharyas, has justified the contradiction by research in the Vishnu Purana and Brahma Purana. This is explained in two other Puranas. In these Puranas, it is said that once the fair denizens of heaven pleased Ashtavakra Muni by their service and were blessed by the Muni to have the Supreme Lord as their husband. Ashtavakra Muni was curved in eight joints of his body and thus he used to move in a peculiar curved manner. The daughters of the demigods could not check their laughter upon seeing the movements of the Muni, Ashtavakra Muni. And the Muni being angry at them cursed them that they would be kidnapped by rogues even if they would get the Lord as their husband. Later on, the girls again satisfied the Muni by their prayers and the Muni blessed them that they would regain their husband even after being robbed by the rogues. So, in order to keep the words of the great Muni, the Lord himself kidnapped his wives from the protection of Arjuna. Otherwise, they would have at once vanished from the scene as soon as they were touched by the rogues. Besides that, some of the gopis who prayed to become wives of the Lord returned to their respective positions after their desire was fulfilled. After the departure of Lord Krishna, he wanted all his entourage back to Godhead and they were called back under different conditions only.

## Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.15.21 - 24 | 10-12-2022
**Speaker:** HH Stoka Krishna Swami

### Krishna's power, devotee empowerment, detachment
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/IEVtBnCURC0?t=45
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "But in the absence of Lord Krishna, all of them at a moment's notice have become null and void."
**Summary:** Arjuna's realization that his powers were dependent on Krishna's presence, illustrated with analogies of clarified butter on ashes, magic wand money, and seeds on barren land.

In this session we will be discussing four verses, verse numbers twenty-one, twenty-two, twenty-three and twenty-four of the fifteenth chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. The twenty-first verse is as follows. The meaning of this verse is: "I have the very same Gandiva bow, the same arrows, the same chariot drawn by the same horses. I have the same horses and I am the same Arjuna to whom all the kings offer their due respects. But in the absence of Lord Krishna, all of them at a moment's notice have become null and void. It is exactly like offering clarified butter on ashes, accumulating money with a magic wand or sowing seeds on barren land." So these words are very significant words, which explain to us that as long as it is required, for Krishna's pastimes, He empowers His devotees with extraordinary power. But these powers given by Krishna are not required for the devotees to go back home to Godhead. They were only meant for Krishna to enact his pastimes. So after Krishna's pastimes have been wound up, the devotees do experience that they do not have the same powers they had when Krishna was present. Like Arjuna, he is having the same Gandiva bow, the same chariot drawn by the same horses, he's the same Arjuna, but now he is bereft of all those powers that he had. With the Gandiva bow in his hand, he could defeat many, many, many powerful Kshatriyas. Now when he tried to protect the wives of Krishna, some gnome-like, cavaad men easily defeated him and kidnapped him. So his Gandiva bow was ineffective. So Arjuna is recollecting that in the absence of Lord Krishna, all of them have become null and void. Now Arjuna is giving three examples of how they have become null and void. It is like offering clarified butter on ashes. When you pour clarified butter on it, it's the beginning of the purification process. If you put butter into a blazing fire and there is sufficient fuel, then the fire will blaze even more strongly. But you pour any amount of ghee into ashes, there will be no fire. Or another example given here is accumulating money with a magic wand. Sometimes magicians they show, display some magic. They have got something called a magic wand, like a stick. They just move the stick and suddenly in their hand there will be so much money. But that money is not real money, it is an optical illusion, it is a magical effect for entertaining some audience. There is no real money there. You cannot get money by just waving one stick in a magic show. There is no real money there. Similarly, sowing seeds on a barren land, it is useless. Those seeds won't fructify, they won't grow, they won't germinate. The land has to be fertile. Then only sowing good seeds will have some effect. Then only sowing good seeds will have some benefit. Similarly, in the absence of Lord Krishna, all those empowerments are no longer valid because Krishna has withdrawn them.

### dependence on Krishna, illusory independence, material civilization
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/IEVtBnCURC0?t=350
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "All energies and powers are derived from the Supreme Source, Lord Krishna. And they act as long as He desires. And all of them cease to function as soon as He withdraws."
**Summary:** Srila Prabhupada's explanation that all power comes from Krishna, using the analogy of an electrical powerhouse, and that material advancement without Krishna's blessing is futile.

So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "As we have discussed more than once, one should not be puffed up by borrowed plumes. All energies and powers are derived from the Supreme Source, Lord Krishna. And they act as long as He desires. And all of them cease to function as soon as He withdraws." Prabhupada gives an example to help us understand. "All electrical energies are received from the powerhouse. And as soon as the powerhouse stops supplying energy, the bulbs are of no use. There are so many arrangements for lighting up a big palace or a big mansion. But as long as there is power supply from the electrical source, the powerhouse, these bulbs will glow very nicely. But as soon as the powerhouse stops supplying energy, the bulbs are of no use. In a moment's time, such energies can be generated or withdrawn by the Supreme Will of the Lord. Material civilization without the blessings of the Lord is child's play only. As long as the parents allow the child to play, it is all right. As soon as the parents withdraw, the child has to stop." Prabhupada is giving an example to help us understand. Human civilization and all activities thereof must be dovetailed with the supreme blessing of the Lord. And without this blessing, all advancement of human civilization is like decoration on a dead body. It is said here that a dead civilization and its activities are something like clarified butter on ashes, the accumulation of money by a magic wand, and the sowing of seeds on a barren land. The blessings of the Lord's blessings, all our attempts at independent existence in this material world are futile.

Verses 22 and 23, they are given together. I will read both of them and then we will hear the translation. Rajamstvayanuprishtanam surdamna suratpure viprashapavimudhanam nignatam mushtibhir mithah varunim madhirampitva madonmathita cetasam ajanatam ivaunyonyam chatupanchavasyeshitah The meaning of these two verses is, "O King, since you have asked me about our friends and relatives in the city of Dwarka, I inform you that all of them were cursed by the brahmanas, and as a result they all became intoxicated with wine made of putrefied rice, and fought among themselves with sticks, not even recognizing one another. Now all but four or five of them are dead and gone." Yudhishthira had sent Arjuna to inquire about the well-being of the Yadus. So now Arjuna is bringing the news, after Krishna's disappearance, all of them, except for four or five, are dead and gone. And how did they die? That is also very bewildering. They fought with each other after becoming intoxicated and killed each other. Twenty-fourth verse, prayenaitad bhagavata ishwarasya vicheshtitam mitho nignanti bhutani bhavayanti chayan mithah The translation of this twenty-fourth verse, factually this is all due to the supreme will of the Lord, the personality of Godhead. Sometimes people kill one another, and at other times, they protect one another. So Arjuna is explaining that as a devotee he knows, supreme will of the supreme personality of Godhead always prevails. And by his will, sometimes people may kill each other. And at other times, by his will, people may protect each other.

So Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, "According to the anthropologists, there is nature's law of struggle for existence and survival of the fittest." One class of philosophers in this world, they are mostly atheists, and they say that this world is working according to the law of struggle for existence and survival of the fittest. But Srila Prabhupada says, they do not know that behind the law of nature is the supreme direction of the supreme personality of Godhead. That they do not know, they cannot see, they cannot understand. They do not know how nature is working. In the Bhagavad Gita, Srila Prabhupada says, "It is confirmed that the law of nature is executed under the direction of the Lord." What is the verse? Mayadhyakshena prakritihi suyatesa characharam Material nature is working perfectly according to the direction of Krishna. Whenever therefore there is peace in the world, it must be known that it is due to the goodwill of the Lord. And whenever there is upheaval in the world, it is also due to the supreme will of the Lord. Both peace as well as upheaval. Battles or wars. Both are according to the supreme will of the Supreme Lord. Not a blade of grass moves without the will of the Lord. Tenavina trinam apina chalati Even a blade of grass won't move without the sanction of the Lord. Completely he is in perfect control. Because he is Paramatman everywhere. Everyone's heart. And every single move by every living entity has to be sanctioned by the Lord. Otherwise, the living entity is unable to act or move. Whenever therefore, Srila Prabhupada says further, "There is disobedience of the established rules enacted by the Lord. There is war between men and nations." So there is a reason why Krishna sometimes wills that there be some fighting or battle between men or between nations. Why? Because there is disobedience to the established rules enacted by the Lord. Dharmam tu sakshat bhagavat pranitam Dharma means the code of conduct given by God personally for all of us. Especially for the human beings. So we have to follow those rules of Dharma given by Krishna. Then everything will be fine. There will be peace, there will be prosperity, there will be plenty of supply. There will be very cordial relations between people. Everything will be very, very nice. Just like when Yudhishthira Maharaj was ruling. When Ramachandra was ruling. When Pariksit Maharaj was ruling. There was peace, there was prosperity, there was plenty of all supplies. People were completely satisfied. They were happy in all respects.

They are always interacting and producing different circumstances, conditions, situations. Satvam rajas tamaiti gunas prakriti sambhavaha. This is explained in the 14th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita.

### material nature, three gunas, conditioned life, surrender
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/wMc6qwXZeXw?t=359
**Verse References:** BG 14, BG 8
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Material nature not only consists of eight elements it also consists of three gunas."
**Summary:** The speaker details the composition of material nature, including the three gunas, and how they create conditions that lead to conditioned life, emphasizing the need for surrender to Krishna.

Material nature not only consists of eight elements, it also consists of three gunas. This is a secret that is revealed in the Bhagavad Gita by Lord Krishna. Generally, people know that material matter or material energy or material nature means the five elements or the eight elements: five gross elements—earth, water, fire, air, sky; three subtle elements—mind, intelligence, ego. But they do not know material nature consists of three gunas: Satva guna, raja guna, tamo guna, and these three gunas are always interacting with each other, producing different conditions. And under those conditions, everyone is living, all those who are under the laws of nature. They are subject to the conditions imposed upon them by the three gunas interacting and producing so many changes. Continuously material nature is imposing different conditions. Adibhutam charo bhavaha. This is also explained in the 8th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita. This material nature is constantly changing, in a state of flux, always, as long as material nature is active, as long as this created world is maintained, constantly in a state of flux. So, therefore we are all subject to these conditions, as long as we don't surrender to Krishna, as long as we don't take to devotional service, as long as we don't prepare ourselves to go back to Godhead. We are subject to these conditions. So that situation under which everyone is forced by material nature is called conditioned life.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/bQqWaOoslBc?t=119
**Verse References:** BG
**Content Type:** philosophy

So Krishna's departure from this world to his personal abode in his self-same form, not change of body. This difference has to be noted. In the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says, "Death means change of body." Now here, Krishna is departing to his personal abode in the self-same form. He never changes his spiritual form. So eternally he is the Lord. But eternally he has his form. Eternally he has everything. He has his energies. He has his paraphernalia. He has his name. He has his qualities. He has his activities. Everything eternal. So this distinction should be understood between material name, material form, material paraphernalia, material activities, material possessions, material manifestation. Everything is temporary. Everything material is temporary. And everything spiritual is permanent, eternal, changeless. As long as Krishna was present, Kali could not manifest its actual characteristic of inauspicious conditions. But when Krishna left this earthly planet, from that very day, Kali manifested, became fully manifest. And the full manifestation means creating inauspicious conditions for those who are endowed with a poor fund of knowledge.

### Yudhishthira Maharaj, Parikshit Maharaj, Responsibilities of a King, Human Form of Life, Spiritual Guidance
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/XY4bYVfQ9Y8?t=50
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Human form of life means a life of responsibility, and the king ensures that people take advantage of this human form of life by becoming very responsible."
**Summary:** This segment discusses Yudhishthira Maharaj handing over the kingdom to Parikshit Maharaj, emphasizing the king's responsibility to guide citizens towards spiritual realization and the importance of human life for understanding the difference between temporary and permanent.

In this session we will be discussing from the 38th verse of the 15th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. स्वराट् पौत्रं बिनैनं आत्मनः सुसमं गुनैहि तोय नीव्याः पतिम् भूमेर् अभ्यसिंचत् गजाह्वये The meaning of this 38th verse is: Thereafter in the capital of Hastinapura he enthroned his grandson who was trained and equally qualified as the emperor and master of all land bordered by the seas. So here is the description of Yudhishthira Maharaj retiring from active household life and he is handing over charge of ruling the world to his trained and qualified grandson, Parikshit Maharaj. Parikshit Maharaj was the only surviving descendant of the Pandava family of the Kuru dynasty. Everyone else was killed in the battle of Kurukshetra. So Yudhishthira Maharaj handed over charge to Parikshit Maharaj and he handed over charge as the emperor and master of all lands bordered by the seas, the whole world. He handed over charge of ruling the entire world to Parikshit Maharaj. Srila Prabhupada says in the purport, "The total land on the earth bordered by the seas was under the subjugation of the king of the Kuru dynasty, the king of Hastinapura." This is the arrangement. The emperor of the world ruled from the place called Hastinapura. Hastinapura is modern day Delhi. Elsewhere Srila Prabhupada explains. So the capital was always in Hastinapura of the rulers of the entire world. There was subordination. There were subordinate kings and they had their smaller jurisdiction of province or state or some small kingdom, but they were always subordinate to the emperor. So that was actually the system, that there were different territorial kings who were protected by the emperor against any invasion by rogues and thieves and dacoits etc. So they used to rule the citizens very nicely according to the scriptural directions, according to the kshatriya dharma, the perfect system of administration given in the perfect scriptures, coming from the perfect source, the supreme personality of Godhead. So Srila Prabhupada further says, "Maharaja Yudhishtira trained his grandson Maharaj Pariksit, who was equally qualified in state administration in terms of the king's obligation to the citizens." Earlier Srila Prabhupada elaborately explained what were the obligations of the king to the citizens. The king had to essentially ensure that all the necessities were provided for the citizens so that the citizens can actually become responsible for preparing themselves to go back to Godhead after having achieved or after having received a human form of life. So human form of life means a life of responsibility and the king ensures that people take advantage of this human form of life by becoming very responsible, not that they are busy simply earning money or busy with some material activities, busy with some sense gratification, all under the influence of the illusory energy for some temporary effects. No. Human being means should understand the difference between the temporary and permanent, material and spiritual, body and soul, matter and spirit. Clear difference or distinction should be made and the human being has the developed consciousness or intelligence or brain substance to actually be able to do this.

### Bonafide Spiritual Master, Material World, Sense Gratification, Different Bodies, Conceptions of Enjoyment
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/XY4bYVfQ9Y8?t=399
**Verse References:** BG 15.0
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "If I want to enjoy like a dog, I should get a dog's body."
**Summary:** This segment emphasizes the need for a bonafide spiritual master, describes the material world as an ocean of sense objects, and explains how different desires for enjoyment lead to different types of bodies, referencing the 15th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita.

Under proper guidance. Therefore scriptures say, approach a bonafide spiritual master who is self realized and who has seen the truth, who is conversant with the subject spiritual subject matter by having properly studied it under another bonafide spiritual master in discipline succession coming from Krishna. These things are all very clearly explained. So these are, that's a creature depending on the type of senses they have acquired, the material senses, there are sense objects and to give an example for a dog, a male dog, the form of the female dog is very attractive, is very attractive. For a male deer, the form of the female deer is very attractive. These type of illusory attractions are plenty in this material world. So one of our acharyas, Srila Bhaktivinoda Thakur, says this material world is like vishaya sagara, an ocean of sense objects. Vishaya means something enjoyable by the senses. For the eyes it is all what we say as beautiful form, form, not form, forms, beautiful forms. For the ears it is sweet sounds. For the tongue it is palatable, tasty edibles and as you know different creatures have different things they consider as edible. For a hog, stool is very much relaxable and is an edible. It eats too. It eats rubbish. Camels eat thorns. And there are different creatures with different kinds of a sense of taste according to tongue they have acquired, according to their desire to enjoy eating or seeing or smelling or touching or hearing. This all simply centered around a concoction in the mind to enjoy materially in a particular way. The business of the living being in this material world, having acquired these material senses, centered around a material mind with a certain conception of enjoyment. Why these different types of bodies, different souls are getting in this material world? Because there are different conceptions of enjoyment. If I want to enjoy like a dog, I should get a dog's body. If I want to enjoy like a cat, I should get a cat's body. If I want to enjoy like a tiger, I should get a tiger's body. So in the precepts, Srila Prabhupada says, "All that is manifested in the material world is a product of the Mahat-Tatva Avyakta, and things that are visible in our material vision are nothing but combinations and permutations of such variegated material products." So the basic understanding is, I am not this body. And this body is one of the many different products of the material elements, which are generated at the beginning of the creation out of the material energy called Mahat-Tatva Avyakta. The material energy in its dormant condition, inactive state, is Avyakta. And when it is activated at the beginning of creation by the glance of Mahavishnu, it becomes Mahat-Tatva, the state in which the material energy becomes activated. Activated means the three gunas become, start working. And those three gunas, they interact with the Mahat-Tatva and produce so many material elements. And those material elements are combined to form this variegated material universe. Different products, different material elements, different objects, and different bodies, everything. So now, whatever we see in our material vision is nothing but the combination of different material objects or products. But the living entity is different from such material products. They are completely different from the body, from the mind, from the intelligence, from the false ego, from the material objects, varieties of material objects.

Srila Prabhupada says Draupadi was the most beautiful daughter of King Drupada, and when she was a young girl, almost all the princess desired her hand. This was also another secret not known to Duryodhana or Dhritarashtra or any of the Kauravas. So when Pandavas agreed to go, Dhritarashtra thought now somehow eliminate the Pandavas. So then the Pandavas actually escaped after going there, and even though the palace was set on fire, the people thought Pandavas were living inside, and they were very, very unhappy that the Pandavas were killed in apparently a fire accident, and externally the Kauravas who knew the real reason why the Pandavas were sent there to be killed alive, burnt alive, so they externally expressed some sorrow, very unfortunate the Pandavas were burnt alive, some accident, but actually practically nobody knew that the Pandavas had escaped. Drupada was doubtful whether the Pandavas were really killed in that fire accident. So in order to discover where are the Pandavas, he decided to actually contrive a peculiar way of arranging a test for the princess to discover where is Arjuna if he is in hiding.

### Jarasandha, birth story, demon, king
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Uq9HxmlW0XA?t=146
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Out of curiosity, she joined the two parts and the child became complete and regained life."
**Summary:** Srila Prabhupada's purport explains the unusual birth story of Jarasandha, involving a king, two queens, a mango, a she-demon named Jara, and the joining of two body parts.

And this Krishna Mantra Prasurtyamantra was a very powerful king of Magada, and the history of his birth and activities was also very interesting. His father, King Brihadratha, was also a very prosperous and powerful king of Magada, but he had no son, although he married two daughters of the king of Kashi. Being disappointed in not getting a son from either of the two queens, the king, along with his wives, left Kashi home to live in the forest for austerities. But in the forest, he was blessed by one great Rishi to have his son, and that Rishi gave him one mango to be eaten by the queens. The queens did so and were very soon pregnant. The king was very happy to see the queens bearing children, but when the right time approached, the queens delivered one child in two parts, one from each of the queens' wombs. The two parts were thrown in the forest where a great she-demon used to live, and she was glad to have some delicate alnya flesh and blood from the newly born child. Out of curiosity, she joined the two parts, and the child became complete and regained life. The king was in a haste. He thought the queens have delivered two parts which are not complete. He thought they are useless. Both the queens have delivered something which is incomplete. So, they simply discarded the parts. But when the she-demon joined the two parts, they became complete and regained life. The child became complete and regained life because the child was born due to the blessing of the rishi in the forest. The rishi blessed that the king have only one child through the two queens, one child. Becoming common, the class 4 queen came out. So, therefore, the she-demon was known as 'jara', that was her name, who lived in that forest where the king had retired, and being compassionate on the childless king, she went to the king and presented him with the nice child. Instead of, she presented the king with the child. The king was very pleased with the she-demon and wanted to reward her according to her desire. The she-demon expressed her desire that the child be named after her. And thus, the child was surnamed Jarasandha, or one who was joined by Jara, the she-demon. Sandha means to join.

So, when Krishna, Bhima and Arjuna asked Jarasandha for the facility of fighting him, to settle that Jarasandha would fight with Bhima only. So, all of them were guests and combatants of Jarasandha. So first of all in the purport he describes Bhadrashva Varsha. It is a tract of land near Meru Parvata, and it extends from Gandhamadana Parvata to the salt water ocean. There is a description of this Varsha in the Mahabharata, in the Bhishma Parva 7th chapter verses 14 to 18. Mahabharata is the history of greater India. So it is called Itihasa. It is compiled by Vyasadeva. So Srila Prabhupada is quoting from this, that this Bhadrashva Varsha is described in this particular portion of the Mahabharata. The description was narrated by Sanjaya to Dhritarashtra about this Bhadrashva Varsha.
