Maharaj Pariksit was formally declared to be the emperor of all lands ruled by his grandfather, but still he had to establish his supremacy while he was out of his capital to exact tribute from such states. The king is not simply a namesake king. He has got his power to rule, and he challenges the subordinate kings. If they accept his supremacy then there is no fighting. Otherwise there is a battle fought between the two kings, and whoever is victorious becomes the ruler. Ketumala Varsha. Another part of his kingdom. This earth planet is divided into seven Dvipas by seven oceans, and the central Dvipa called Jambudvipa is divided into nine Varshas, or parts, by eight huge mountains. See. So there are seven oceans dividing the earth planet into seven islands. The land mass between two oceans, surrounded by water is called an island.

So Srila Prabhupada explains a significant point to be noted in these verses. In the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "Kings and great personalities of the state are presented with welcome addresses." This is the Vedic culture. This is a system from time immemorial, and Maharaj Parikshit, since he was one of the well-known emperors of the world, was also presented with addresses of welcome in all parts of the world as he visited those places. He was a very great emperor, so naturally people would welcome him. A great personality is welcomed when he visits a certain place. People who are conversant with his greatness, they will glorify him for the benefit of everyone else. The subject matter of those welcome addresses was Krishna. This is the most important point. How is it that Krishna is the subject matter of all those welcome addresses when Parikshit was travelling in different parts of his kingdom? Because Parikshit was a great devotee of Krishna. Parikshit's forefathers who were ruling the earth planet, the Pandavas, they were also great devotees of Krishna. So whether somebody glorifies Krishna or Krishna's pure devotees, always the subject matter of such glorification is Krishna. That's why the Bhagavatam, which contains nothing but the glorification of Krishna and his pure devotees, is also called Krishna Samhita. That means it is that special Vedic literature, Samhita means Vedic literature, which is exclusively devoted to descriptions of the glorifications of Krishna.

No. Just like they say, Desh Bhakti, devoted to the country. That word Bhakti cannot be used, strictly speaking, for somebody who is very devoted to, who is patriotic. The word Bhakti cannot be used. Bhakti refers to devotion to Krishna only. So even if somebody glorifies the devotee, that glorification will necessarily be glorification of Krishna only, because devotees are all the time thinking of Krishna, speaking about Krishna, remembering Krishna, doing every activity for the sake of pleasing Krishna. That is Bhakti. So Srila Prabhupada further says, "Maharaj Pariksit would not have been glad to hear about the glories of his forefathers like Maharaj Yudhishthir and Arjuna had they not been connected with the activities of Lord Krishna." This is a characteristic of a devotee. He is not simply attached to his family members like ordinary people are. No. His attachment is for devotees. His attachment is for Krishna and Krishna's devotees. The devotees are glorified by the presence of the Lord because they cannot live for a moment without the presence of the Lord and His different energies. This is the symptom of a devotee. A devotee always wants the presence of the Lord. And how does a devotee always be in the presence of the Lord? By constantly thinking of Him, by constantly remembering Him, by constantly chanting His name, by constantly hearing about His glories, by constantly engaging in different acts of devotion and service to Lord Krishna. So therefore, Maharaj Pariksit felt the presence of the Lord when Krishna was glorified by His activities, especially when Pariksit was saved by Lord Krishna in the womb of His mother. So that reminded him of Krishna. Whatever glorification people did simply reminded Pariksit of Krishna.

The bulls are used in so many ways, at least in the Vedic culture, for drawing water from the well, for removing the husk from the grains after they are grown, for extracting oil from oilseeds, for transportation. The bull can pull. It has got an immense amount of strength to do all these activities. And the cow delivers milk, the miracle of aggregate food values. So, cow is specially meant for giving us milk, which is meant for our well-being, that it contains all the nourishment and nutrition that we require as human beings, particularly the cow's milk is highlighted. So, if the cow and bull are protected for the good of human society, then there is advancement of Brahmanical culture. Brahmanical culture is a culture meant for self-realization, spiritual realization, spiritual advancement. And if the bull and cow are neglected, or worse still, they are killed for being eaten as food. So, that is done by people who do not know the value of Brahmanical culture. They are uncultured, uncivilized, non-Brahmanical people. They have no spiritual values in life. They have no higher goal in life. Simply they live like for eating, sleeping, mating, defending, like animals they live. So, then if the cow and bull are mistreated, then the whole human society has to suffer in so many ways. And that is what is going to be described in the next few verses. I will stop here. Thank you very much.

### Distress, Internal Disease, Separation, Sanskrit
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/37GcMWFJ8oo?t=131
**Verse References:** SB 1.16.19
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "You are covered with the shadow of grief... Are you suffering from some internal disease? Or are you thinking of some relative who is away in a distant place?"
**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on the verse, explaining the meaning of each question posed by Dharma, highlighting the cow's distress, potential internal suffering, and possible separation from a loved one.

So this symbolic representation of the condition of human society reflected in the condition of the cow, the representative of mother earth, the cow. And even the condition of the bull, that will be described in the next verse, the condition of the bull. So dharma is inquiring from mother earth, madam addressing Bhadre. This is a respectful way of addressing a lady in the samsara. In Sanskrit language, Bhadre, madam. Are you not hale and hearty? Are you not keeping good health? Are you not happy? Why are you covered with the shadow of grief? That means not only is mother earth unhappy, but she is unhappy about something which seems like it is a cause for distress or unhappiness. Continues to linger for a long time. It's not something which comes and immediately goes away. It's not like a pinprick. That momentarily there is some pain and after the cause for the pinprick is removed then the pain is gone. It's not like that. You are covered with the shadow of grief. And it appears by your face that you have become black. That means the pain has been there. The problem of this cause for the pain has been there, and your face has become black because you have been suffering for quite some time, a good length of time. Are you suffering from some internal disease? And what is the cause of your pain? Why are you suffering? Some internal disease? Is there some disease that has afflicted you? Or are you thinking of some relative who is away in a distant place? You are separated from your relative, and you are not able to live together happily. You are separated, and you are not able to actually be together due to some reason.

So this chapter describes how Parikshit received the age of Kali. Parikshit ascended the throne as the emperor of the world after Yudhishthir Maharaj. Then he married and begot four sons. He married the daughter of King Uttara. So Srila Prabhupada explains the purport. Maharaj Uttara was the son of Virudhara. And this Maharaj Uttara was the maternal uncle of Maharaj Parikshit. Why? Or how is this relationship? Because when the Pandavas were living incognito in the kingdom of Virudhara, Arjuna was instructing Virudhara's daughter. So, of course Arjuna was in disguise as a dance teacher. Then when later on Virudhara came to know that this Arjuna as a dance teacher was not ordinary dance teacher but he was Arjuna. Then Virudhara wanted to marry his daughter to Arjuna. But Arjuna refused because Arjuna said as a teacher I am like the father. I am in the position of a father. So I can't marry her. But my son can marry her. So Arjuna's son Abhimanyu, he married Virudhara's daughter. Now Parikshit is the son of Abhimanyu. So Uttara, sorry, Iravati, the daughter of Maharaj Uttara, who is the brother-in-law of Abhimanyu, is actually a cousin to Parikshit. So Iravati was a cousin sister of Maharaj Parikshit. Maharaj Uttara's daughter and Abhimanyu's son Parikshit were cousins. So Srila Prabhupada says cousin brothers and sisters were allowed to get married if they did not belong to the same gotra or family. So this is the important point. Even though they are cousin brother and sister, they can get married if they don't belong to the same gotra. Gotra means family.

Then it is described here, Janamejaya celebrated several sacrifices in the Kurukshetra pilgrimage site. Kurukshetra is famous for being a holy place. Dharmakshetre Kurukshetre. So, this Janamejaya, he performed several sacrifices in Kurukshetra. Why would they perform sacrifices? For the welfare of the citizens. They are really responsible kings. And it is also described here, Janamejaya had three younger brothers named Shrutasena, Ugrasena, and Bhimasena II. So he had three younger brothers also. He invaded Takshashila Rajanta and he decided to avenge the unlawful curse upon his great father, Maharaj Pariksit. Later on it will be described that is, Pariksit was cursed to die by snake bite. So this Janamejaya, when he learnt about it, he wanted to take revenge against the snake which bit his father. According to the curse. So what did he do to take revenge? This is Janamejaya. He performed a great sacrifice called Sarpayagna. To kill the race of serpents. He wanted to kill all the snakes. Because one serpent bit his father. Of course, his real anger was against Takshaka, one of the serpents. One of the serpents who bit his father. Because his father was cursed to die by snake bite. Particularly Takshaka's bite. So this Janamejaya arranged a Sarpayagna to be performed by qualified Brahmanas. And his aim was to kill the race of serpents, including Takshaka. Now on request from many influential demigods and sages, he had to change his decision to kill the race of serpents. That means, when he undertook this sacrifice, he was told by, advised by many influential devatas and sages and saintly persons, don't do this. Don't simply kill all the serpents. This is unfair. This is not proper. And then he actually agreed to stop the sacrifice when he was instructed or advised by many saintly persons and even devatas not to do this kind of sacrifice to kill all the serpents.

So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, nirvana vilambitani. That is explained specially by Srila Prabhupada in the purport. What does it mean? In the purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "The activities of the Lord include liberation, but they are more relishable than the pleasure derived from nirvana or liberation." This is a very important point. In bhakti, liberation is a secondary benefit or a secondary result of practicing Bhakti. In fact, those seriously practicing pure devotional service are not at all interested in liberation, are not interested in any of the four Purusharthas, not interested in dharma, artha, kama, moksha. Why? Because the activities of the Lord, which are the essence of all activities of Bhakti, they are more relishable than the pleasure derived from liberation. Millions and billions of times more relishable. The description is given in the Bhakti-rasamrta-sindhu, Nectar of Devotion, this book, written by Srila Rupa Goswami, describing the characteristics of pure devotional service. Srila Rupa Goswami says, quoting authentic Vedic references, he says, "The pleasure derived from liberation is so very insignificant as compared to the pleasure derived from pure devotional service, that even one drop of pleasure of pure devotional service cannot be compared with an ocean of pleasure that may be derived from liberation. The two cannot be compared at all." That means, the pleasure derived from pure devotional service is billions upon billions of times greater than the pleasure of liberation. So therefore, devotees who are seriously practicing in knowledge the system of pure devotional service, they are not at all interested in liberation.

All circumstances. There are many examples given. Just like Arjuna's life was in danger on the battlefield of Kurukshetra, and Krishna will protect Arjuna under all circumstances. Now, in doing so, Krishna had actually broken his promise. He had promised that he will not take any weapon. He will not fight in the battle. He will not take any weapons. As long as he is in the battlefield, he will never do that. Arjuna's life was saved. For the moment, Arjuna's life was saved. And after that, when Bhishma surrendered to Krishna, Krishna actually did not attack Bhishma at all. Krishna's purpose is served. Arjuna is saved, and Bhishma is also Krishna's devotee. So, when he surrenders, that means, he is not going to fight anymore. ### lotus feet of Krishna, devotional service, shelter
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/UQB_jav9ggQ?t=860
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "devotees are accustomed to licking up the honey available from the lotus feet of the Lord."
**Summary:** The speaker explains the concept of taking shelter of Krishna's lotus feet, describing the spiritual planet Goloka Vrindavana and the honey available in the lotus flower, symbolizing the relishable nectar of devotional service and the constant desire of devotees to be sheltered by Krishna.

Now, Srila Prabhupada explains what is this licking up the honey available at the lotus feet of the Lord. Prabhupada says the spiritual planet Goloka Vrindavana, the eternal abode of Krishna, is shaped like the wall of a lotus flower. Even when the Lord descends to any of the mundane planets, any of the planets in this material world, He does so by manifesting His own abode as it is. Krishna's abode comes down with Him. When He comes His feet remain always on the same big wall of the lotus flower. And His feet are also as beautiful as the lotus flower. Therefore it is said Lord Krishna has lotus feet. You would have heard this many times. Krishna's feet are described as lotus feet because His feet are always resting on the lotus flower. So there is a certain honey available in the lotus flower, and that honey is what the devotees are accustomed to tasting when they take shelter of Krishna's lotus feet. That's why devotees are attached to Krishna's lotus feet, and that honey is as relishable as nectar. Therefore constantly the devotees want to be sheltered by Krishna's lotus feet. And that's why it is said devotees are accustomed to licking up the honey available from the lotus feet of the Lord. So to take shelter of the lotus feet of the Lord means to be engaged always in a relationship with topics of devotional service to Krishna. That is the meaning of taking shelter of the lotus feet of the Lord. I will stop here. Thank you very much.

### death, material science, limitations of the body
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/E-7pQuc0ZJE?t=133

**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on Srila Prabhupada's purport, criticizing modern science's attempts to avoid death through physical means, emphasizing the importance of the spirit soul over the perishable body.

So what is the meaning of this? Shudra Prabhupada explains in the purport: The living entity as he develops from lower animal life to a higher human being and gradually to higher intelligence becomes anxious to get free from death. It is to get free from the clutches of death. We know nobody wants to die. We all know that. But then death is forced upon us. So in the human form of life, we have developed intelligence to understand how can we become deathless. That is the prerogative of the human being because of developed intelligence. Modern scientists try to avoid death by physiochemical advancement of knowledge. Modern scientists, they do not know the real self, the spirit. They think only in terms of the body. But this body is always a dead body. It appears living because of the presence of the spirit soul. Otherwise this body is always a dead body because it is made of matter. It doesn't have life by itself. It doesn't have life. So any attempt to avoid death by analyzing the chemicals, by manipulating the chemicals or the physical body, this is never going to work. So Srila Prabhupada says, even though they try to avoid death, the controller of death, Yamaraj, is so cruel that he does not spare even the very life of the scientist himself. The scientist who is trying to do research, how to avoid death by some chemical manipulation, even that scientist himself has to die. So nobody is spared by Yamaraj. The scientist who put forward the theory of stopping death by advancement of scientific knowledge becomes himself a victim of death when he is called by Yamaraj.

So Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, what does this mean for us who are living in Kali Yuga? It has got a lot of significance this description here. The principal sign, Srila Prabhupada says in the purport, the principal sign of the age of Kali is that lower caste's shudras, what does it mean lower caste shudras, men without aristocratical culture and men without spiritual initiation would be dressed like administrators or Kings and the principal business of such non-Ksatria rulers would be to kill the investors. Innocent animals, especially the cows and bulls, who shall be unprotected by their masters, the bona fide vices, the mercantile community. Sushila Prabhupada clearly explains a often misunderstood terminology. In the Vedic scriptures, in the description of the varana and ashrama system of dharma, it is described that the society should be divided according to occupational duties and according to spiritual development into four varanas and four ashramas, four social orders and four spiritual orders. Now, this varana classification has become completely topsy-turvy in this Kali Yuga because of the misunderstanding that one belongs to a varana according to birth in a certain family, which is not. What is explained in the scriptures, clearly in the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says, the quality based on qualifications, based on the qualities possessed by a person, that person should be classified according to the qualities and according to the occupational duties. The one who performs the same occupation according to the work he performs, according to the natural inclination to work in a certain way, a person should actually be classified as a brahmana, kshatriya, vaishya or shudra. So very clearly who are to be classified as shudras, those who do not have brahmanical culture and they do not have spiritual initiation. Sushila Prabhupada explains. That means they are more or less godless people and they are bereft of the brahmanical culture. They are uncultured. According to Vedic description, they are uncultured. So, uncultured, godless people are to be classified as Shudras. Not according to birth. Regardless of which type of family they take birth in, it doesn't matter. If they are uncultured, if they are godless, then they are to be classified as Shudras. Such people will be considered as Shudras. They will be dressed like administrators or kings. This is the sign of Kalyuga.
